Pros: PlayStation is an iconic brand, and people love us. Our mission is to push the boundaries of play and ultimately to make people happy. We aren't solving for world peace or saving lives so the stress isn't at a crisis level. There's just enough to fuel your days with some excitement. Working here is different than any company I have ever worked for. First, people of all backgrounds seem to want to work here--there is no shortage of people applying to our jobs. Second, we have incredible benefits at an affordable cost. And our benefits are expansive--IVF coverage, backup child care, etc. --amazing! Third, the people PlayStation is bringing in are best-in-class leaders who are helping shape the future of the company. It's a great time to join. Forth, we stand by the communities we live in. PlayStation committed $100M to social justice to improve lives and increase opportunities for underrepresented groups. Our commitment at PlayStation to DE&I is like nothing I have ever seen. Fifth and final comment: the people here are very supportive of one another and friendly. It's a happy workplace.
Cons: PlayStation at times can seem like a giant start-up. There's a lot of transformational work happening. Pros: - Work life balance is good and flexible working hours - Extra Christmas and summer company shutdowns (adds a few free days to your total holiday) - Good pension scheme (double contributions up to 10%) - Colleagues are generally nice (with a couple of notable exceptions at the manager level) - If you want a job where you won't learn or do much but want to have an easy 9-5 and get paid at the end of the month, PlayStation would be a good fit
Cons: - Work itself is more like a simple Data Analyst role but with the name Data Scientist, with little actual Data Science involved - Few learning and personal growth opportunities available - Slow moving and little innovation (due to company size, but also the kind of people who stay aren't ambitious due to the environment - the more driven employees leave) - A couple of the managers in the UK team are very inexperienced (and quite frankly, bad at their job) due to a couple of quick promotions to manager position and it shows - we recently had an anonymous department-wide survey (with lots of questions, but generally focussed on if you are happy in your job), and the Data Science team had the worst results in the department in which the team sits (of around ~10 other teams). I do see this as a manager-level issue (not director level - the director of the team is OK) - the managers seem to be out for their own gain and not for the gain of their direct reports

Review Title: Miserable Leadership / Terrible Work Life Balance
Pros: A decent place to work if you're into games, but that's about it.
Cons: PlayStation (Sony) is a miserable place to work, and here is a non-exhaustive laundry list of why: 1.) Compensation: First off, compensation is weak and far from competitive with the market. My offer letter included no signing bonus, and there are no stock options for the vast majority of employees, even at the manager level. 2.) Work/Life Balance: Since the huge "globalization" effort, separation of work and life became impossible. I would wake up for 6 AM meetings and then take 10 PM meetings in the evening. Leadership did little to support a healthy work/life balance and would respond to people outside of working hours, expecting swift resolutions at odd hours of the day. When I was a Manager at Sony, someone on the Marketing Team took their own life. It took that tragedy for leadership to respond with resources and workshops for mental health. 3.) Out of Touch: Everyone director-level and up is a straight, white male that is insanely out of touch with the world at large and clueless to how other tech orgs of this size operate. As boomers, they feign a sense of care for DE&I initiatives, spew corporate poo poo words, and think that's enough to cover their butts. 4.) Cult-Like: If you're not into the industry, you are immediately ostracized like an outsider. Be ready to fake a passion for gaming or forever be an outsider to the cult. 5.) Org Hierarchy: The structure at Sony is extremely hierarchical, and employees are not empowered to make decisions. Instead, be prepared to be stifled for trying to innovate or implement change.

Review Title: Leadership is incredible and Management is terrible
Pros: The leadership is fantastic. You will be hard pressed to find more visionary, likable and intelligent leader in your department. They have a clear vision of the future of the company, the possibilities and it's incredibly contagious. They will give you a lot of vigor to fulfill their dreams so that the customer is well taken care of. They're also not afraid of taking their own risks and trying new things (as long as it meets their superiors agenda). As much as they will deny it at PlayStation, a love of gaming is near required. Which is a pro if you have a affinity for games. A con if you are not.
Cons: Management is incredibly powerful and they keep that power for themselves. The simple fact is that you were hired for a job, and for that job only. While some companies hire for creativity, intellectuality, boldness. You are at PlayStation to fill your cog in the machine. Giving me the feeling of being a Temp / Contractor more than a Full Time Employee. For example, exploring other aspects of PlayStation (let alone Sony) is near impossible due to the dozens of security, management protocols and other walled garden approaches that the company has taken in order to enforce this. However, the leadership within PlayStation or those who have their ears, will enjoy pushing the boundaries of entertainment while taking advantage of PlayStations bright and friendly workforce. In summary, if you're looking for a company ready to invest their dime in you to take risks or explore in any facet of the word without being in a position of power, then you best look elsewhere.

Very competitive pay for new hires, which is the only way to get paid market rate here Excellent employee discounts Generally good benefits Very interested in diversity; diverse candidates should definitely apply - just don't stay long enough that your pay falls behind.
Cons: Zero effort to maintain current compensation for employees. Work/Life balance is a marketing blurb, not a commitment. They will tell you that you shouldn't work more than 8 hours a day and 5 days a week, and should use your vacation time, BUT will also hound you about maintaining deadlines which require 60+ hours a week to meet. Repeated statements that compensation will be brought current, but with NO follow through or broad correction, over a multiple year period. It's disingenuous at this point and the company is bleeding long-term talent because new-hire salaries are currently following market rates and going crazy, but no meaningful adjustment seems to be planned for existing employees. Review Title: "A Great Place to Work and Play!"
Pros: PlayStation is such a great place to work. I look forward to coming to work everyday and enjoy the people, the environment and the scope of work. Instead, it is such a huge benefit because we have the autonomy to work independently, yet all the benefits of the support and funding from such a huge corporation. Every work area has a gaming station and you are encouraged to play during work hours! How crazy fun is that! Plus, having the opportunity to work so closely with the executive team, I am able to see clearly our mission and why what we do is important. Passionate people, phenomenal products and great benefits! Also, pay is great and the bonus program is killer, not to mentions the perks like deep discounts on ALL Sony products, matching 401K, generous medical and dental and the PTO and paid holidays makes it easy for work / life balance.

Most of the high-achievers have already left so what remains are lazy "lifers" and the naive who do not know any better (do a search on the "dead sea effect").

Pros: Though the culture can vary wildly from department to department, there is overall an emphasis on the individual "making things happen." This is generally a good thing, provided that you are someone who can. Strong emphasis on personal relationships. The more people you know, the more you understand the way the company works and it's many components, the more successes you will encounter. This is not a company for somebody who needs to be nursemaided 24/7, or who is devoted to formal processes. If you possess talents, are good with people, take the initiative, and possess some measure of patience you can go very far.
Cons: It's not for everyone. Successful employees tend to put a lot of effort into decoding the large and complex org. I wouldn't recommend this company to anyone who wasn't open to putting in at least two years of service before passing judgement - this place takes time, but the benefits can be worth the wait. Hardware product business succeeds in large part due to strength of console. Software business needs fresh thinking.

Pros: - Weekly lunches - Bagel/donut Fridays - Central SF location; close to transit - Cool brand recognition; looks great on a resume - Good work-life balance - High visibility of product - People are passionate about building great products - Healthy relationship with product and engineering - Efforts to create a fun culture: game launches and swag, karaoke, version release parties, Christmas parties, hackathons, happy hours
Cons: - Senior management is a mess - out of touch with employees and current technology, false transparency, lack of objectivity across all team members, inability to establish baseline of trust with all team members, does not inspire confidence, all buzzwords and no real communication - Below-market compensation - Constant political struggle and general low morale - Projects are routinely killed - It's a well-known fact in the Bay Area that contractors are treated like second-class citizens and are at best strung along for years - Process and progress occur at a glacial pace - Constant conflict with Tokyo office - their word is law and they are beyond feedback - Sterile cube farm - Low diversity - No employee development/lack of mentorship - Feature bloat - Verticals are completely siloed - Huge gaps of time in between projects - No one gets fired but they are managed out (demoted, compensation is cut)

Review Title: Lots of potential, great brand, but no commitment to team or tech innovation
Pros: A few very talented and passionate co-workers. Day-to-day chaos can lead to growth opportunities, if you can manage to keep your head above water and work past it.
Cons: Huge amount of attrition at every level and function. In less than a year, I watched 70% of my team leave. 2 top executives quit outright (giving no notice), leaving their positions unfilled until a year plus after. New middle and senior management has little to no experience in the space. The culture is becoming increasingly conservative, cliquey and less diverse as the parent company struggles financially. Said passionate and skilled workers were burned through, weren't recognized for their efforts, and left. Successful or innovative work is considered threatening and not rewarded. Not-rocking-the-boat is encouraged. Remaining and new employees are necessarily apathetic and mediocre in order to survive. Zero career growth paths. Strategy is often abandoned and teams are randomized due to pet projects and poor operational planning. Groundhog Day.

Pros: - Sony Discounts on electronics tvs and such - Free games - Working on games and different IPS - Quite a relaxed work enviroment except crunch periods - Overtime paid at 1.5 x
Cons: - Constant reminders you are a 3 month contractor ( Emails specifying only for 12 months or permanent staff) - No job secuirty ( They can finish you up mid-way through a contract) - Opportunities tend to go to those who have been there the longest or know the higher ups - Leads soon forget all overtime and additional work you have done and are more concerned about the now - Refusing overtime is held against you to a degree - Can be transferred to a new project at a moments notice ( New test lead - Boss to impress) this leads you top be at the bottom of the totem pole and more likely to be terminated due to lack of interaction with new test lead at renewal period. - Very little transferrable skills games testing is looked down upon in the software testing industry leaving experience only valuable at another games company. - Hard to rise out of the QA department or obtain a permanent position in QA.

Review Title: A very pleasant and respectful place to work and explore career interests!
Pros: The environment is great. The employees are friendly, courteous, and helpful. Supervisor was friendly, courteous, respectful, and communicative. He attempted to relate and engage with you on a personable level and provide flexibility, support, and discretion for how you chose to pursue objectives, as well as feedback and resources for personal learning and development and encouragement to learn about different areas and departments of the company that might be of interest to you.
Cons: I did not feel there was a downside to working for the company itself. I had ample opportunity to learn the material and concepts that I was interested in even though they weren't directly part of my core tasks, as well as the opportunity to meet and learn from other industry workers who lent their experience and willingness to answer questions about the industry. The only issue that could have been improved was the occasional confusion over reporting of work hours as an intern, partly because they prefer you not to log hours overtime, and because new hire orientations can happen months to over a year after your start date.

Pros: This is one of the best jobs I've ever had. I have a great boss, great teammates, the work is interesting and our end users are engaged and passionate about our products. If you watch tech news, you know that PS4 is doing very well in the market, which is energizing for the teams working on it. The new management is passionate about making sure the customer experience is everything they expect, and are driving real change to overcome some past problems. There are a lot of perks working for Sony, including great benefits, movie premiers, hackathons, game tournaments, off-site team-building events, and discounts on products. Sony also has a great diversity program that's very friendly to women.
Cons: Any time you drive change, there are going to be some growing pains. I think it's improving, but they're still working out some kinks. The size of the organization also means you lose some agility since development has to be coordinated across multiple teams.

Review Title: Central and Northern CA office cultures should be your target.
Pros: Health and Wellness Benefits Online Gaming Benefits Employee Discounts Onsite Perks Free Parking
Cons: My recommendation is to avoid opportunities in the Rancho Bernardo office. Rancho Bernardo office culture is Siloed and Stifling. Yes, the salary was good but it really wasn't about the money. I felt stuck and stifled. I had already been there for 3 years and I could no longer handle the obscurity of its culture, lack of direction and transparency. The workload was too high and the pressure was constant. Additionally, having a manager constantly breathing down your neck was disheartening. C-Level leadership based in this office lacks vision and strategy, as well as the fortitude and insight to do what's necessary to generate process improvement and forward momentum. Don't take my word for it, check out the pictures on the company profile.

Review Title: Employees matter, management cares, still a growing company
Pros: The land of opportunity with endless possibilities. Not a perfect company, but we've grown a lot over the years and now are moving towards a new era of positive changes and a well-defined direction. The vision is clear, management wants to make it a better place for employees. We have countless meetings run by upper management to force us to give them feedback. Yes, we are all locked in a room together to collaborate...feels like electing a pope where no one is getting out until we are done...only we have food, snacks, and breaks. They listen and make changes to improve our overall culture. Culture is pretty laid back. Facility is amazing. Benefits are improving. Great holiday parties.
Cons: No defined career paths for employees. How can I get promoted if there is no standard guideline? How can I take myself to the next level? Communication could be improved from manager level to employee. There are management-specific meetings, but seems as though information stops at the manager level. How can I help you if I don't have the full picture? Documenting our goals is always an afterthought. Telecommuting isn't really promoted. Not enough family events and no daycare.

Pros: - Super fun and great people - Strong team dynamic on some teams - Easy to get the ear of upper mgmt if you know the right people - Lets of challenges and areas to lead improvements across all functions - Relatively easy to look like a strong employee if you have basic stills (communication, documentation, follow-thru)
Cons: - Management is scattered and unclear on strategy and that shows at all levels (a lot of "do it because I said so" type management) - Company is complacient on current strong product lead creating lots of egos leading vs trying to look forward - Poor employee development, lots of people that have been there for years in the same type of role who are good but cannot be great because there is no movement or real direction on how to improve - Always saying to think "global" but no actual global execution or support from mgmt

Pros: Working for sony network entertainment is very rewarding because you get to work on something that is in the face of millions of users. This is extremely large scale. It's exciting and fun to know that you are part of something big.
Cons: The new untouchable upper management that was pulled in from intuit is ruining this company by striking fear in everyone and firing good employees. Mediocre VPs with no experience bring in directors of engineering who have never been an engineer just does not make any sense. It's hard to respect directors who acts with a brute force without even understanding the perspective of others. They completely threw away everything we have been working so hard on and come into the company demanding to rebuild everything for the sake of rebuilding. The moral is really low in the company and it kills any innovation because we have no freedom to innovate.

Review Title: They care for customers, not so sure about employees
Pros: Hands on with gaming consoles and games. The company strives hard to keep customers/gamers happy by keeping content fresh and introducing new technologies. Lots of talented and passionate employees work here. The "cool" factor about working at a gaming company, your family & friends flock towards you at parties/gatherings.
Cons: The gaming community as a whole are very spoiled customers compared to other industries. They get to whine and complain about the smallest details about games and consoles that will cause the Nintendos/Microsofts/Sonys to have knee-jerking reactions to their strategies and decisions. This often comes at a price of causing stress to employees in forms of constant team restructuring, projects being in constant flux, management changing directions, layoffs and OFFICE POLITICS. If you can't handle being thrown under the bus or not being sure whether people are talking $h!t behind your back, don't work here or at any gaming company!

Pros: Worked on many KICKASS games with some awesome people.
Cons: Worked for the company as a "Contract" employee for 8 years. To get around the laws of California they would "lay me off" for a few months then have me back so they didn't have to pay for my benefits. I loved what I did but management refused to give reviews, pay raises or hire me on full-time even though the position was available and I had received a Masters Degree in the same field. That all isn't the worst. The worst was after 8 years they "ghosted" me. Basically, they told me they were going to lay me off for a few months, then when I contacted them repeatedly for when my start date was...NO RESPONSE. I thought these people were my friends ...The biggest slap in the face was my job was posted on their website 3 weeks later. ....Thanks Sony San Diego!

Review Title: Great gamer culture, great growth opportunities, some shortcomings
Pros: Great educational, medical and transportation perks - Great bonuses and employee discounts on PlayStation and Sony products - lots of opportunities to travel overseas, particularly to Tokyo or London - Supportive leadership that Lets employees explore different Career paths and grow - Passionate coworkers who love gaming and are really into what they are doing - a low-conflict environment with a Strong drive for consensus and respect - Agile development practices with continuous improvement, hackathons and quick adjustments based on lessons learned - work from home opportunities in The U.S. and management focused on Results, Not attendance - a quirky and creative environment typical of The gaming industry - a company that encourages playing games at work - a very approachable CEO and most other top leaders - lots of women in leadership positions, even in Japan (mostly up to Sr. Director level but also some VPs)
Cons: - Incompetence is sometimes tolerated indefinitely, true to the life-employment model of Japan - Managers frequently lack the most fundamental people management skills and don't know how to motivate their employees - Lack of open conflict leads to a lot of back-channeling, politics and having to read between the lines - In the Tokyo office, expectations about work hours are insane and no one can work from home, which leads to female workers still largely being forced to choose between having career success and being single, or having a decent but unimpressive job at PlayStation and having a family - The super-Agile style of the San Fransisco office frequently clashes with the Waterfall thinking of Tokyo - As of 2018, analytics is still not a big part of decision making and a lot of product managers are weak - Employee performance management is unpredictable and convoluted. There are no company-wide OKRs and it's hard to understand how performance goals are measured

Review Title: Sometimes fun, but often a let down
Pros: So many of the people are incredible and the products are really fun. The games, the people, the culture of play could make it into a terrific place to work... But
Cons: There's massive chaos right now on what the company will become. They've had three new CEOs in 18 months, and their Network still lags behind the competition. Overall, the company is in major upheaval, which is surprising and often creates some major confusion about where one fits. Companywide functions are really underpowered -- some are barely even paid attention to while others dominate. So often, stuff happens with in one function in a complete silo, and then it breaks across other groups.

Review Title: Volatile environment with no respect for employees
Pros: There are some very talented people at SNEI in San Diego who work hard to achieve results, believing in doing the right things. The business has challenging goals to achieve and they will likely succeed with proper attention to delivering experiences to beat their competitors. Salary is good and the onsite gym is great. Culture there is fast-paced but allows for company outings to get to know your colleague and just to have a good time.
Cons: The business is volatile and can be crushed easily by their competitors if not done correctly. The turn-over is high and I've seen people let go immediately with no notice and there's a hush-hush attitude about it. Work environment is fierce so you have to be careful whom you may disappoint or else management will easily let you go, I've seen it with my own eyes.

Pros: SNEI is a great place to work. This division of Sony only started about 6-8 years ago, as opposed to SCEA which has been around a while. Anyway, because its new, you feel like it almost has a start-up feel to it even though its such a well-established company! People really care about your growth here, they want to hear your opinion and your input, and they are very smart people! They're also super down to earth. The quality of work is amazing you get to work on an entertainment platform - games, movies and music!! I definitely give it the highest rating!
Cons: There are always some negatives to a job (certain employees, processes' etc) but its all what you make of it. Its like taking the bad with the good, but generally I see everything is pretty great at this place

Review Title: Good place to work for but effective management is a bit lacking.
Pros: Working at PlayStation is pretty fun if you love video games. The work environment is laid-back in general. The company is not a stickler for when you get in or leave. People are pretty understanding if you need to leave early for personal reasons or need to take a few days off for vacation. The employees are nice and it's relatively easy to become close to the people you work with.
Cons: In the time I've worked here, I've come to realize the company is not as organized as you hope it would be for such a big corporation. Communication is lacking and sometimes things aren't done effectively or on time because of this. I think this partly has to do with how many people are involved in one project. With so many people, there is a tendency for projects to lose focus because there is not one person or group taking ownership.

Pros: Anything that PlayStation makes you get for free! Very generous PTO policy. Company is closed between Christmas and New Years with pay. Cool products and great brand recognition. Merchandisers get to make their own schedule with some parameters.
Cons: Being a merchandiser used to be a fun job. You got to meet different people and every day was different. But now all we do is go to the same store every weekend and demo VR. My work life balance has gotten really bad. I work almost every weekend and I often work 8 days in a row or more because I am still expected to perform my normal duties along with the weekend work. I am getting burnt out.

Pros: large-scale - really Great engineers - Weekly lunches - benefits
Cons: - 25% of the advertised compensation was a yearly bonus. Don't be fooled. Depending on when you join it might be 1.5 years before you get it. - Also, if they decide you are not worth what they're paying, which base salary is already below average, they will string you along until just before bonus time and cut you with 0 days warning. - Also, and this is a first that I've ever heard of in the Bay Area, no severance whatsoever. Yes, none at all. Nothing. No 2 weeks pay, no warning, no here's rent money until you find something. Just, don't show up any more. - They work you like a start up but you have none of the creative input. - Management is incompetent and out of touch with the technologies and decisions. - Politics. A friend who spearheaded a major initiative to change the entire server deployment process, working day and night, did not get a promotion while the manager is taking all the credit.

Review Title: Used to be great, recently lost its way
Pros: - The individual contributors are very good. They're smart, driven, and very easy-going. - The benefits and perks as part of the Sony family are great: Good health plans, huge discounts on sony products, free playstation games, etc. - Workers are encouraged to develop their skills by learning new tech and attending training and seminars. - Work / life balance is great. People are given flexibility as long as the work gets done. - Office culture is relaxed and casual.
Cons: with one or two exceptions, middle management is Toxic, tribal, and self-serving. - Zero opportunity to move up in your Career - Pending merger with SIE is causing dread and rumors about job security, made worse by silence from Upper management. - office space is outdated and falling apart, management has no plans to do anything about it.

Review Title: Used to be a good place to work.
Pros: The people were good. Discount on Sony products. Occasional in-house happy hours. Ability to watch some movies pre-release. Without question, the company brand name was good.
Cons: Once the Sr Mgmt crew (all formerly from another well known company in the area) came in and took over things started to go downhill. The company used to support Scrum but started doing things that seemed to be very contrary to agile practices. The attitudes of the new "leadership" was very negative, at least towards existing SNE employees. They were better with the ones they brought in from their former company. This caused many to feel they were being adversarial.

Review Title: Independent place that lacks direction and vision
Pros: Informal atmosphere, good benefits, good time off. People can be very friendly.
Cons: The company feels like it lacks direction. A great deal of bureaucracy strangles innovation. Company feels like it's loosing it's competitive edge in the age of online gaming. HR is a nightmare. No solid plan for advancement within the company. Company doesn't mentor. HR has no strategy in place to retain top talent. Pay is low. Talent is mediocre. Japanese style hierarchy and decision making structure is out of place in Silicon Valley. The company "events" have become an embarrassing joke (karaoke in the parking lot anyone?).

Pros: Sony has a good work/life balance. SNEI revenue is growing rapidly and should continue to do so for at least the next year or two. Most people working there who are not former Intuit employees are good people to work with.
Cons: Over the last year a new executive in the San Diego office has been aggressively clearing out people and installing yes-people from Intuit. We're not just talking about clearing out people that perhaps needed to go, but clearing out anyone that asks questions. The entire atmosphere of innovation, collaboration, and desire to produce the best result for the company has been replaced with one that punishes innovation and enforces conformity and acquiescence over all else.

Review Title: It's all a ploy for cheap labor
Pros: Having PlayStation on your resume is cool, telling your friends about it is cool, and the free swag is cool.
Cons: Don't expect to be valued as an actual part of your team. I was often left with no projects and when I asked for more, my peers and manager would tell me they were busy and I couldn't help them. There was a lot of politics even from an intern level. Although the dress code is laid back, the culture in general is not. I saw many team members staying late to meet deadlines and could feel the stress in the air. Sony will tear you apart and does not value their employees. It also sucks because they offer a lot of contract roles and you never know what your status may be with that. Very little information was offered to me in my performance review and I was never told how I could improve or what could have gone better.

Pros: Working on PlayStation and being a part of the video game industry. The PlayStation ecosystem is always on the cutting edge, and the time I spent there was during the PS4 launch so it was doubly exciting. The passion and enthusiasm many of the employees have for what they're doing is unrivaled. It wasn't uncommon to find people who just loved what they did.
Cons: Management was terrible. The value of human resources was lost on many people, and the people in positions of power were too interested in saving face to make sure their workforce was being managed and treated properly. There were countless situations where management was aware of a terrible work environment but actively avoided the subject and did nothing to rectify the situation.

Pros: Good place to learn, gain experience and make connections. The London office is in central London with a lot to do nearby, great restaurants and culture. You work for Playstation which people are generally know and interested about. You work with game studios and technologies that will be used in future games and media. The culture is inclusive, you will find many different looking faces here. There was no crunch and a pretty good work-life balance in my team.
Cons: Lot of company politics to deal with, secrecy and distrust between different teams. Lots of emails on the start of day and multiple meetings per day that are unproductive. Collaboration between different regions is sparse. Some internal systems that are being used are ancient. Salary is a joke, people working at Playstation are often living in house shares in London, and you will not be able to save up on an Engineer salary.

Pros: I worked as Department Operations Manager. Average employee experience compared to other companies in the Bay area. HR people are nice and receptive but a mouthpiece for the Sr Directors and VPs- forget employee advocation! Nice HQ, good holiday parties. Good learning module on employee central. Legal people are also very collaborative and friendly. Good Pay and bonus.
Cons: Facilities workers are efficient but the managers are totally narcissistic. R&D department is run like a concentration camp. Have no idea how to efficiently manage people. Slave drivers rather than inspiring team to engage. Very Very hierarchical, political charged culture, employees with Japanese background are favored and not reprimanded- high level of Nepotism. Not at all entrepreneurial. Employees not promoted based on merit, but based on their national origin (or who they know).

Pros: Benefits, culture, free food and drinks, parties, my management is awesome (YMMV), opportunity to explore different things, some work from home, flexible hours, tons of paid time off.
Cons: Perks like holiday parties are declining, upper management cuts money on necessary small return items and spends liberally on unnecessary stuff; high turnover and onboarding of every single application anyone wants creates a lot of work and hemorrhages money, but they cut spending on office cleaning and other minor expenses. Merging of SCEA and SNEI has been appallingly inept and there has been little or no engagement of stakeholders for anything.

Review Title: Formerly a good workplace, now going down hill.
Pros: Discounts on the limited selection of first party games.
Cons: Pay isn't great when they're trying to compete and act like a tech company. Benefits are mediocre and don't compare to other companies in the area. Big distinction in work place benefits compared to their first party studios. No employee development or major support towards paying for education. Educational support is on the low end.

Review Title: Best Place I've Worked to Date
Pros: Sony Interactive Entertainment evolves and changes to improve not only innovations to become more profitable but I really feel like they care about their employees. They continue to improve processes and policies if they aren't successful. Fantastic benefits package Emphasis on work/life balance Great coworkers - lots to learn from others There is a sense of community to solving problems (lots of support from others) Wonderful company goals that are actually strived for
Cons: At least in my department, meaningful self improvement training budget has been cut which is a bummer. As in many places, opportunities for advancement are limited but there is a balance to be met here between becoming too management heavy but I think SIE does a fair job of figuring that out. I really respect the executive team and believe they have a good vision for the company, however there are some middle managers that tend to play politics instead of focusing on improvements.

Review Title: Company with good perks, but the system is suffering from a lot of growing pains
Pros: Good perks if you are a gamer. Benefits package is alright. The company is an industry giant and has market leadership.
Cons: The system is so entrenched in a kind of boys club attitude. Time spent in the company, deference to leaders, and maintaining the status quo are the main concerns. You will be thrown out if you do not move with the grain or if you question how things are done or try to think outside of the box. The way they treat contractors is embarrassing. Pay is much lower than a good majority of the Bay Area companies. The benefits package is alright, but there are no stock options. The company is still smarting from globalization and if you are on a global team, you can pretty much kiss your work-life balance goodbye.

Review Title: Don't apply if you want to progress
Pros: Games given out to staff on launch date for free. Occasional raffle for freebies. Cake table at end of the month.
Cons: Unless you're in a certain circle of people don't expect to get an interview for a promotion, even if you've worked hard at the company for years. People are promoted based on favouritism and not experience/skills which leads to some staff lacking in skills to manage a team. Certain seniors abuse their position and treat testers like children, some going so far as to bully staff and get them into trouble. If a person is favourited they can get away with pretty much anything, even if a higher up witnesses them doing something bad. Test floor gets super toxic whenever a new position gets announced and some staff don't hold back on saying what they think of others capabilities.

Pros: Very nice campus. Good benefits. Nice cafeteria. Some fun perks like monthly $10 game vouchers and discounts on hardware. A week and a half shut down during the holidays which is good for full-time employees, but not contractors (which don't get paid).
Cons: Some inexperienced employees waste multiple team's time and energy by being reactive and flip-flop in their decision making. This wastes time and energy for multiple teams and is frustrating to be effected by inexperienced employees with too much power. Pay is below market rate and hours are inflexible (9am-6pm).

Pros: Projects, people and location. You will be able to apply to a huge selection of studios if you spend a few years here.
Cons: Contract oriented, static pay, no upward mobility or broad knowledge learned. If you want to focus on the core of being a cinematic animator, you do that here. Get in some beach time while you are at it because you may not want to wait five years to move up the ladder or get a raise. It is a well known fact in the studio that you have to leave and come back to get a meaningful raise, and you might find yourself priced out of the studio with how competitive the rest of the industry is now.

Review Title: Not a place for ambitious people
Pros: * Amazing product (PlayStation!!!) * If lucky, you get to work on very visible parts of the products * Get to try pretty cool games or tech (Morpheus) * Nice campus
Cons: * Work/life balance can be poor - a few people do all the work - others do the minimum * Don't even think about being a contractor there: you will be treated like garbage * All key decisions are made in Japan, no involvement of US people in the decisions * Impossible to have a relevant role or any ambition - dead end for your career * Low compensation compared to the rest of Silicon Valley * Management aware of all these problems - not doing anything about it.

Pros: The culture here is pioneering. Not quite a startup anymore, rather an organization striving to grow. Not for everyone. People who excel here are ingenious, see around corners, have an “anything is possible” outlook, live for the mission, are cool to work with, possess tons of resilience and are really top in their craft. Personally, have a great boss, great team and super cool work to do. It's not by any stretch an easy job - but it's one where I make a difference every day and have fun doing it.
Cons: The org is behind in building out infrastructure and systems. Organizations have a lot of autonomy - but it also results in silos.

Review Title: Major Issues - Too Many 'Lifers', and Not Open to Change!
Pros: Decent benefits package Ok work/life balance Relative Flexible Schedule
Cons: - Employees that have been there a long time no longer have to prove themselves. Too many old fat cats. - New employees are held to a different standard. - There are double standard and unfairness in how employees are treated. Too many old 'cliques'. Somewhat like high school. - Communication from ANY management level is sorely missing. - Change is at a snail's pace.

Review Title: Enjoyable at times yet taxing almost always
Pros: - I get to work with a product I've grown up with and love. - I get to work with some of the coolest people I've ever gotten to know. - The team you get really starts to become family after a while.
Cons: - Favoritism is a huge issue here and the only ones promoted are those on the inside, not the qualified. - Management doesn't really disclose things that are pertinent to our job ahead of when we'll need the information. - We're often left blindsided by some of the issues that happen and our stats are used against us even if it's a new issue that we don't know how to resolve. - The turnover rate here is pretty high and good agents leave due to management's lack of transparency/flexibility or other stupid reasons.

Review Title: Great place to work with exciting products touching millions of users
Pros: Once in Sony, you will have a hard time leaving, it is hard to beat when the products and services you are in charge of affects millions of people around the globe. Lot of opportunities to grow and at the same time enhance exciting products and services. Great and smart people. International culture and opportunities for working abroad.
Cons: Being part of a huge organization often also unfortunately mean slower in many aspects as there are more stakeholders and customers to consider and keep happy, which can be frustrating. Large old solutions that takes a lot of time to change and keep up to the changing market.

Review Title: Very nice company with dedicated enthusiastic employees
Pros: Company culture overall is great. All employees want to or think they are doing the right thing, very few really bad apples (tho some incompetence). People really are company's strongest asset. And of course PS4 is such a great product to be associated with. Business is booming and lots of excitement over new SIE formation.
Cons: Some employees need more guidance than they're getting. Still seems like poor performance (behaviours that are self-promoting rather than for the good of the business) is not sufficiently counseled to stop. Lots of valuable time wasted this way. Also, poor performers need to have good workers cover their poor performance, further setting the company behind.

Review Title: A great industry somewhat undone by over-reliance (and staffing) at the senior management level
Pros: Sony is a company with a rich brand history and this makes for an interesting work environment. The video game industry is still in growth mode, which creates an environment where contributions can be made at all levels (of course, provided that management allows for such contributions to be made). Entertainment is a integral part of people's lives and working for a company that develops entertainment product puts one "front an center" in this part of lifestyles. Benefits are reasonably good at Sony and the fact that many video game companies, including Sony Computer Entertainment America, are closed over the Christmas holidays is a nice perk.
Cons: Room for advancement is limited, particularly in certain functional areas. Japanese run leads to some complications when trying to address US or European markets.

Review Title: Great company on the cusp of being Excellent
Pros: The products we work on are amazing, innovating, and inspiring The benefits are great Lots of vacation time to decompress from working hard Having all the technology available to complete your work Management encourages initiative and responsibility, you're not just a cog
Cons: Growth opportunities can seem slower, not provided, or not communicated how to achieve. Sometimes someone from outside takes a position in which an internal promotion would have been a better fit. Trickle down of information lacking. There are lots of innovative, exciting things happening and new directions SNEI is moving, but this information sometimes doesn't trickle down. Try to bring those high level meetings back down to the employees.

Pros: The benefits and stability here are great, especially for a company in this field. And, this is from someone who was laid off. They are also one of the top game companies, when it comes to paying their full time employees a good salary.
Cons: Although their salaries are great, the raises aren't, even with top yearly review scores. Over the course of 6-7 years, I received a total 9% raise. The actual salary was still better than all other places, but in a better market, I probably would have looked elsewhere. #2 absolutely no career advancement opportunity. Everyone is pretty much locked in place.

Review Title: Fun and challenging company with a bit of an addiction to managers.
Pros: - Very laid back environment - Challenging work - Small, fast-moving teams - Get to work with and develop some extremely cool tech - Since being acquired by Sony, work hours have been reduced to "normal". - Lots of company sponsored events for the employees.
Cons: - Company is a bit "top heavy". It feels like every new person who gets hired is a manager or a manager or managers. Most of which, I am not even really sure what they do on a day to day. - The release process is a bit painful, but it is improving.

Review Title: Good Company with a little too much management
Pros: - Incredible people (intelligent and creative) to work with - Amazing work/life balance. The occasional worked weekend is sometimes given back in lieue (worked two weekends in 5 years - one was returned). - Generally cool with semi flexible hours. 8:30-5, 9:30-6 or anything in between.
Cons: some of The projects have a lot of management, and its Not really obvious what all of them do. - Legal is a joke. they do Not actively know what The requirements are for a lot of games, but tend to simply require The harshest restrictions possible. Advice: never suggest anything to legal. get them to return specific requirements.

Review Title: Fast, fun and exciting place to be. Working on the cutting edge and possibly changing an industry.
Pros: Everyone is great to work with. Most people are smart and hard working. Plenty of team building events throughout the year. Lots of little perks.
Cons: They will work you to the bone day in day out. Expected to work long hours. There is no real structure to projects. Most of the management have unrealistic time tables. Difficult to move up in the company. A bit understaffed. On the lower pay scale for this type of company. No appreciation of the hard work accomplished when going above and beyond the call of duty.

Review Title: A place to kill your time but not to develop your career future
Pros: flexible working hours; every year there is a holiday shutdown between Christmas and New Years day... that's the only pros I can think of...
Cons: too many/frequent changes at management level, senior managers/directors come and go, the working experience in the same company is not recognized by itself, incapable mid-senior management team, almost the entire DB department is called Indian team which implies its recruitment might not be a fair play, too many politics at all levels, you have career future here only if your manager likes you personally, work performance has nothing to do with it...salaries of same level engineers from different groups can be a huge difference...over the long term it's a sinking ship...

Review Title: good place to get a big name on your resume
Pros: Friendly work environment Great company perks like happy hours, company events, holidays, etc. Great brand with a lot of pride in the work, work is extremely interesting and fun Company is doing well as a whole
Cons: Do not contract here - they treat contractors differently than they do FTE. There are no guarantees you will be hired once your contract is up Very political culture as is every big company - hard to move up in the company if you do not have the right 'relationships' Management only looks at success based on team as a whole - does not look at specific individuals (aka there are a lot of terrible managers that slip through loopholes)

Review Title: Lucky that games are selling so well
Pros: Good salaries, benefits, work/life balance. Exciting technical problems to be solved. Engineers work well together and have respect for each other.
Cons: You know if the company has to pay for a featured review to refute the other bad reviews and blame existing problems on past management (even though new management has been around for over two years) then there is probably a problem. Almost all middle level development managers (who have been there more than a few years) have left (or fired) because of contention with upper management. Development direction is based on good principals, but lacking in details and leadership.

Pros: - The people at PlayStation are passionate about the products we're assigned to, and its apparent in our work. We are pushed hard to accomplish a lot with little time. - There are many resources from within the company to manifest outward facing communication. - on-site gym and cafeteria.
Cons: we work so fast, that we forget about our own careers... and HR does Not seem to care. our goals for The fiscal year are written within The last two month of The year, rendering them meaningless. - Prerequisites for promotion are vague. when a straight answer is obtained from management, The Prerequisites change by The end of The year, making promotion impossible to achieve. some employees stay in The same position for a decade (or more) before promotion.

Review Title: Crummy work environment - lack of inovation
Pros: Some of the coworkers are really great friends and companions and fun to be around. Great for people without experience to get a head start and move up in a corporate environment.
Cons: Terrible work life balance, 40 hours a week is considered not enough by management, which as a programmer is pretty bad. Worked for months until 8 or 9 o'clock at night plus some weekends and was still reprimanded for not working 'hard enough'. Management would intentionally steer away from new technology and favor the old just to get products out faster. Constant unrealistic deadlines set by inexperienced managers who have no knowledge of software development themselves.

Review Title: Great opportunities to learn, grow, and keep healthy W/L balance!
Pros: Always exposed to new and interesting topics. Plenty of opportunities to grow and learn. And the work-life balance seems very healthy overall, with a few exceptions.
Cons: Although they've made a lot of progress in recent years, there really needs to be more coordination, communication, and better organization between all the many parts of Sony. It is very challenging to work with all the different parts of the company scattered all over the world. On the other hand, it certainly makes for plenty of fun work-related travel. This company definitely has the resources to make great things happen, but still lacks the coordination among all its disparate parts.

Review Title: PlayStation Europe (London HQ) Great people and culture to work for
Pros: Dynamic and exiting working culture which doesn't overwhelm or stress employees with tight and unreliable deadlines but it encourages creativity and innovation. Also it has recently started to substantially improve how PlayStation look after its employees with initiatives such as flexible working, new facilities including a gym, or session well-being related. People there are amazing and its a classic to pop down to the canteen on Thursdays or Fridays after work to have a drink and have a laugh with your colleagues.
Cons: Rather than a con it's more a challenge the company has come across due to its impressive and fast growth over the past years, specially since PS4 launch, which has made that the company structure and some behavioural process are still catching up with that fast growth.

Pros: Decent workspaces, new computer every couple of years, flexible hours, on-site health club and cafe, most of the employees are smart and motivated to make the best product possible.
Cons: The recent management shakeup has been driving people out of the company by telling them that everything they've done for the last 7 years is crap and it all needs to be redone. Not the way to inspire loyalty.

Pros: Pay is OK - bonus is Above average - socials and PlayStation consoles available if you find time to play
Cons: leadership heavy, powerless managers of all kinds for a single project - department Director gets The final say on every Small decision - be prepared to work late shifts and holidays supporting production even for SW Engineering positions - people being hired (previous coworkers) without proper interview and causing lots of issues - Horrible HR tools

Review Title: SNEIntuit "Leadership" is Proof of "Be Careful What You Wish For"
Pros: The overall PlayStation product line and offerings are something the employees are proud of. The engineers and the line managers are hard working and competent. The grassroots attempts of perks and innovation programs are cool. Just not fully supported by upper management. Job security and overall company performance is positive. As is the work/life balance flexibility. There are times when we need to work off hours and off holidays, but the flexibility of daily activities makes up for it.
Cons: 2 years ago, there was a leadership void in San Diego. The solution was transplanting Intuit employees up a ladder rung across the board atop SNEI employees. However, the leadership above line managers are not new leaders, but simply new managers. All Intuit employees coming to SNEI for promotions in your career beware, your "contributions" are not completely welcomed. Simply assuming you know best without asking questions or listening to feedback is an ignorant approach to management. Force feeding architecture and projects and getting acquiescence is not a sign of agreement but simply a sign of fear and sense of hopelessness. There is no trust. Some of the new regime are decent human beings, but others are simply egotistical, arrogant, micromanaging, over their heads, inexperienced, and disconnected from human interactions outside their circle of trust. All of this goes without saying that career movement opportunities is non-existent unless you break into the circle of trust.

Review Title: Great Brand, Great People, Poor Management
Pros: One of the coolest brands in the world and amazing products with a healthy financial outlook. Great people and working culture in EU.
Cons: Middle Aged White Men's club. A lot of management have been there more than 10 years and lacking diversity in both management style and ideas. How well you get on with your seniors more important than your output. Literally no performance management, have many examples of people coasting for years doing nothing. Trying to be a global company but nowhere near in terms of organising themselves wasting loads of resources and time. IT services in Europe stuck in 90s (example migrated from Lotus Notes to Outlook only 3 years ago!)

Review Title: Burnout Culture and Bad for Women
Pros: PlayStation is a great place to work for anyone who wants to make a serious career in the gaming industry. Having PlayStation on your resume opens a lot of doors. You should also consider PlayStation if you prefer an indirect conflict resolution style because the company culture discourages open confrontation and disagreement. A lot of alignment is done through back channels. Lastly, PlayStation is a good place for anyone interested in the Japanese language or culture. Japanese is used for product development discussions on a daily basis and the corporate culture is similar to what you see at big corporations in Tokyo. There are also frequent business trips to Japan (outside of the COVID pandemic).
Cons: - Burnout Culture At PlayStation, you'll have unnecessary meetings until 8 or 9 pm three or more times a week, without anyone asking if you have small children, or what exactly your children are doing while you are stuck in unplanned video conferences. None of these meetings are useful or necessary. Most of them never even needed to be an email. They are tedious status updates that go on for 2 hours and suck the spirit out of everyone. 10 or 14-hour work days are common, and no one knows why or what for. Nothing is automated, everything is in Google sheets or 60 Slack channels. Everything is always on fire and not being available is unacceptable. Vacations don't belong to you either, and your manager will pull you into meetings during vacation time too. PlayStation seems to have imported the concept of "karoshi" (death from overwork") from Tokyo into Silicon Valley. - Terrible for Women As a woman at PlayStation, please prepare yourself to have supbar maternity benefits, the least desirable projects and performance reviews filled with gender-biased language. All of the most important product development always goes to the bro-culture dudes and there is a general lack of opportunity for women. Men always talk over women in meetings and no one ever stops them. Men also attack women when they are not available for meetings due to childcare conflicts or during no-meeting hours. PlayStation isn't at all interested in supporting mothers. That said, to create an appearance of caring for womens' issues, PlayStation has a number token womens' initiatives, except they are run by men and do exactly nothing to empower PlayStation women. During the COVID pandemic, PlayStation women were hit especially hard. Managers asked mothers to take paid vacation days to support their kids' virtual school. The CEO was extremely tone-deaf and kept sending messages about his sports interests and his barbeque parties as PlayStation women came together to cry because the loss of childcare was ruining their lives and their company didn't care. A lot of the company gender discrimination seems to be based on covert patterns of gaslighting. Not promoted or empowered? It's because you are incompetent, not because you are a woman (never mind statistical data). The company has consistently refused to release gender-based pay data. If you are a woman, just say no to this company. - Horrifyingly Bad People Managers. If you haven't had your share of bullying, yelling, humiliation and continuous put-downs, PlayStation is the company for you. Old-time individual contributors get promoted to people managers and then there is no one to keep their abusive behavior in check. If you are unhappy, please prepare yourself to accept a severance package because HR will never believe you or take you seriously. - Biggest and worst of all, PlayStation leadership is incompetent and runs the company on their gut alone, while serious players come into the gaming space with analytics and data-driven insights. PlayStation is stuck in trusting its long-time "bros" and their gut feelings. PlayStation will go the way of Blackberry unless it wakes up.

Pros: People are nice and helpful. The brand is great and the overall vibe is good.
Cons: Senior management is like and old men club. Really old school. You need to be friends with senior management and flatter them to get noticed or to make any career progress. Also, there are so many layers of management that it is almost impossible to change processes of get things properly done or sorted, and by the time these are looked into, you are just indifferent. Everything takes for ever. From a manager to look at a small request, to making important tools or software available to you. Ultimately, there is no accountability whatsoever, so it is really easy to get unmotivated after little time. Arrogant attitude towards partners ... Fun place to work but for one year max.

Review Title: Nice place for a young person......but then move on.
Pros: Free t-shirts and games. Decent pay.
Cons: Nepotism + favoritism + ageism + blind faith  dysfunction. After making record profits in 2018, Sony Interactive Entertainment (also known as PlayStation) laid off a bunch of talented hardworking people a year later. Do you really want to work for a company that acts like that ? I heard Facebook and Google are hiring…. Sony is just another stupid corporation, and it is top-heavy with executives and directors. Like any other corporation, they treat staff unfairly, as there is a culture of nepotism, favoritism, ageism, and blind faith. Many older employees have been pushed out since 2015. Problems fester for years because the overpaid execs are too lazy to actually care. I was at Sony for 10+ years and I saw many smart, experienced people lose their jobs. Sony has a history of dumping smart, talented people. Their constant use of temp staff is extremely unethical. Sony has improved a little over the years, but it still has the common corporate problems: age discrimination, negative and chaotic management, lack of direction, lack of planning; lack of work-life balance. SONY Interactive is a nice place to work when you are young and need experience. But it's best to move on ASAP and get a job at Google, NVIDIA, Facebook, or Apple instead. Don't bother waiting for a promotion, because for many people it will never come.….You're better off jumping ship and going to some other company. Maybe in twenty years they will figure out how to grow up and be a smart company. All the free popcorn and t-shirts won't make up for the bad karma Sony has earned. Even when they make huge profits, much of that money gets sucked back to Sony headquarters in Tokyo, so your raise and bonus is not as great as it should be.Sony is still suffering from bad decisions that were made back in 2006 by upper management. Directors don't listen to staff, and they don't take time to communicate to the staff. Petty and passive-agressive behavior is standard among upper management. Sony is still having growing pains.

Review Title: It is what you make of it
Pros: was Able to essentially create a full time position for myself with responsibilities that another company may Not offer me. - Awesome co-workers.... enjoyed going to work every day - we were treated like adults, allowed to work from home whenever necessary. Just get your work done at a high level, and everyone is happy - Great opportunities to travel to SF, London, and/or Tokyo
Cons: - Sony is too big of an organization. Getting things done can take painstakingly long. - HR wouldn't budge on intern compensation. - In the beginning we got all kinds of perks (Free lunches, office parties, etc) but these went away with our new budget.

Review Title: We are here to make money.
Pros: Free 12-month PS Plus .
Cons: A good example that shows this company's ethics: About 1 year ago the company provided free 12-month PS Plus to its employees. What they did not say is that this will be an auto-renewal subscription. After 1 year employees have been charged $49.99 for the PS Plus renewal (BTW PS Plus really sucks), and If you request a refund of your money you have to wait 2 months. The company literally calls this refund a " Gesture of Goodwill." Like if it is coming from a higher power. This is how this company cares about its customers (its employees), they simply don't. They are in business to make money, they care less about your experience as a customer or employee.

Pros: Employee discounts on Sony Electronics, PlayStation hardware and games
Cons: No collaboration between teams - everybody is fixated on their own P&L. Mediocre people, who know how to navigate the intricate politics thrive in this environment, where as motivated people who require recognition of their talent leave. Pay is below market for most positions, therefore the quality of most of the staff is also below market. Overall reigning carelessness and covering the bare minimum. Feels almost like a government organization, both in terms of the abundant red-tape and the lack of engagement of employees.

Pros: Good people, nice benefits, fun culture and great opportunities. Nowhere will ever be perfect, but the company is generally a great employer with sensible and approachable management who do care about the success of both the company and the staff.
Cons: Generally speaking I don't have a lot of complaints about the company. PTO used to be a gripe but was recently improved along with several other new benefits in 2016.

Pros: Teams work well together. The work environment is friendly and positive. The work is varied, and you are unlikely to get stuck working in obsolescent technology. Job stability is very high and the pay is generally good.
Cons: Management has no vision. Most of the work you will do will never make it to market. Directions change faster than products are developed. It is very typical to let multiple departments compete to address the same need, resulting in multiple products, most of which are flushed. Product design is typically driven by politics, not by consumer needs.

Review Title: my experience working at Playstation has opened alot of doors and opened my eyes.
Pros: the best reasons to work at Sony Platstation are: flexible hours, brand recognition, great benefits package for full & part time employees, free stuff, nice pay scale.
Cons: downsides of working at Playstation are the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing and causes confusion in the field. HQ employees seem to be condescending to field employees. Unfair promotions for women and especially older women. Seems to be a "good ole boys" club run by one person.

Pros: SCEA has great work/life balance. In the past, it provided great advancement opportunities. There were many social opportunities to interact with employees in other departments. People were very friendly. Paid time off at the holidays was awesome.
Cons: Management has been trying to improve the company for the past 3-4 years, but each change continues to diminish morale. New management does not value the contributions of the employees who built the company. "Lifers" has become a negative term instead of one of respect. Old management is trying too hard to please new management, and the "Sony Way" has been lost.

Review Title: Fun Industry but Very Poor Executive Management
Pros: Great product, friendly co-workers, fun industry. I loved work here at PlayStation, mostly because of the industry. I learned a lot of what NOT to do!
Cons: Executive Mgmt is clueless. PS Move, 3D and PS Vita are all failures. PS Mobile will be the next failure. I don't have a lot of confidence that Orbis will sell well as I don't see it selling to the casual audience. They simply don't need it. The company is quickly losing support of their 3rd Party Publishers.

Review Title: Best place to play (work) in Madison!!!
Pros: - Great pay and benefits! - Tons of holidays - Management is a joy to work for - People, people, people!! The team is great, full of smart dedicated people! - Good discounts on Sony things! - The PlayStation is booming!! - Occasional travel to San Diego and San Francisco. Seriously, if you want to have fun doing what you do, what could be more fun than PlayStation, especially in Madison? There are only a handful of companies here that can compete with the Sony for compensation and what would you rather work on? Medical data? Insurance? Construction? No thanks, I'd rather work for PlayStation :)
Cons: It is a large corporation still, so there are The occasional annoyances that way. but The Madison office is Small and mostly insulated from them

Review Title: Okay place to work. Beware of the yellow badge.
Pros: There are some great coworkers here who are very hard working and are passionate about their work. Also, SCEA produces some great products that you can be proud to say you help develop/market.
Cons: Being a very Japan-centric company, there are certain rules, boundaries and restrictions that keep this place from moving forward and keeping up with the competition. Also, this company liberally uses contractors as expendable workers who they run through regularly with no sense of appreciation.

Pros: Good people, occasional paid trips if you're in the right department, good benefits such as pension and travel allowance, the prestige of being able to say you work for Playstation
Cons: Poor pay, too many middle managers who contribute very little, poor facilities and tools to do the job, people held back in their careers and not given the chance to grow. I was also aware of female members of staff being paid less than their male counterparts, however I'm not sure how widespread across the company this was.

Pros: Relaxed Environment. Some minor events to promote LGTBQA+ events.
Cons: Can be too relaxed. A lot of staff sit with social media up, or sit on their phones No progression - A lot of 2+ year staff with no promotion or raise in place. Paid at same level as new staff. Multiple teams with no say on who or what you work on. Erratic changes to staffing and assigned projects. Several staff have missed out on being credited in games due to changes near the end of a project, damaging their CV and future. Base QA Staff are treated differently. Hired through recruitment agency Yoh! Base QA Staff are exempt from special offers to Sony staff, insurances, special events

Pros: Nice neighborhood, free coffee. A couple of fun perks, such as free Sony Music CDs and a $10 voucher to spend monthly at the Playstation Network store online.
Cons: Low pay, long hours. If you're one of the "in crowd"--meaning you had a prior relationship with management--you get treated with a lot of respect, and are made to feel like part of the team. If not, not so much. Senior management all men with no kids--not much consideration for > 20-somethings with families. Not real big on self-criticism/project postmortems, which helps explain the ongoing poor performance (technical, not financial) of the Playstation Store.

Review Title: Was great at first but went downhill in my time - maybe getting better though
Pros: excellent vacation and perks. had some of my best times there and can be extremely fun & satisfying place to work if you are under the right management.
Cons: Started off great under excellent manager but my negative experience was due to changing over to different manager who was a bully so this may not be your experience.

Review Title: A very rewarding place to work
Pros: Company values and goals have significantly changed during my tenure. Originally it was the Wild West, with corporate politics and petty small-office backstabbing leading the fray. Significant changes in middle management and new policies from upper management have changed the culture to the point where loyalty is desired and rewarded, rather than keeping "King of the Hill" silo-based ethics.
Cons: Despite the positive changes in culture, opportunities for advancement are still very limited and rare, primarily restricted to management-tier jobs. There are plenty of lateral-movement job opportunities though, as Sony expands its cloud services with Gaikai.

Pros: Tested pre-release video games - a dream job for any Gamer. Very tight-knit community amongst QA staff. Great new campus with modern amenities (cafe, arcade, gym). Commuter benefits. Frequent game launch events on campus.
Cons: Cliquey. Siloing of divisions can make you feel like a stranger. Not all divisions appreciate the same perks (flex schedule, WFH, standard business hours). Individual contributions can be difficult to map to high-level Company Vision and Direction.

Review Title: Cheap games but you pay for it in other ways
Pros: Cheap games, Fantastic relocation package, good pay, great benefits
Cons: Leadership, work hours are unrealistic, expectations are not communicated well, the clique from Intuit is well known and highly resented, no work-life balance, working from home is taboo

Pros: Very good benefits. Talented co-workers. Long Christmas break.
Cons: Ineffective leadership and poor employee appreciation. Goals are not clearly defined, and you are reviewed upon incoherent goals created a month prior. Confusing structure, long hours, and poor treatment of employees. Very little opportunities to move upward and no tools to help you grow. Talented people do not stay very long. Elitist and very boy's club. No female VPs ever. Brilliant women have either been laid off, left, or are not promoted. VPs hire their buddies or ...groomsmen. Does not pay competitively, HR will low-ball you so they can get their bonus. HR covers management's rears. And a handful of them act inappropriately.

Pros: Good pay and benefits, nice perks, decent office, Starbucks, cafeteria.
Cons: Toxic culture all around. Ex-Intuit leadership uses bullying, intimidation, and public humiliation to strongarm people into their ways. Japanese culture is typical hierarchical, micromanagement, imitation of your superiors, rule following, and don't color outside the lines to command and control the staff. The result is there is no leadership at Sony because the focus is all on managing down to control the Engineers and tell them how to do their job. To add, since the Japanese culture is robotic and lacks human empathy, they do not understand or recognize the criticality of soft skills and human interaction in business leadership, so tend to make poor business decisions and hiring decisions.

Pros: Working with really smart and creative people. Independent thinkers, even in the legal department people are fun, open-minded and know how to have fun while working hard and knowing their stuff. Great time off after Christmas (don't have to take your vacation hours), Pay is decent but not astounding, bonuses are good for those who do their work and do it well.
Cons: Can get competitive or weird among certain individuals who are very unique and maybe a bit off. They are a bit behind the times in tech resources for a tech company. Legal department employees use a somewhat annoying database, and the email system was backwards when I worked there. I hear they've since upgraded it.

Review Title: Perfect if you don't ever want to advance
Pros: Exciting industry, cutting edge enterainment products. Flexibility to plan your schedule from Jan-October. Get to try the products first, huge discounts on PlayStation products.
Cons: Disorganized R.A.D. department that doesn't give you the tools to effectively do your job and manage your territory. Absolutely no opportunity for advancement, as they fill 100% of the open management positions from outside the organization (within the past 3 years anyway). Unattainable goals, too much work in too short of deadline to get completed.

Review Title: Used to be a good place to work....
Pros: Good career starting company. Competitive pay and bonus. Great brand name to be associated with. Not a lot of stress at work and balance of work/life. The CEO of Sony has turned the failing company around. For now.
Cons: Merger with the Network team from San Diego polarized the Playstation group. Team and group politics are rampant. People in power promoting their cronies is open and unabashed. Management from Japan seems to have no pulse of local technology developments (iPhone, Alexa, ,,,,). Or about the people who work in the US. Decisions from Japan on local processes and tools makes things worse.

Pros: Working on the highest quality games was exciting. You get to work with some of the smartest game makers in the industry on cutting edge hardware and software. Working for PlayStation gives you instant credibility with just about everyone because the brand is so loved.
Cons: Working with a lot of personalities can be difficult, and as a game company there is always a lot of time pressure.

Review Title: Want to work for a real company?
Pros: SNEI has great benefits: medical, dental, 401k, stock options, tuition reimbursement, paid vacation, paid holidays, Friday bagel/donuts, milestone parties, training, just to name a few. The environment is very casual, jeans are normal everyday attire for most. There is an onsite cafeteria, gym (membership not included, but it is fairly inexpensive), bank and cafe. Employees are expected to work hard but are also rewarded accordingly. SNEI employees are surrounded by knowledgeable and intelligent colleagues. SNEI works with leading technology, evolving as technology changes. Low employee turn-over and the company is doing exceptionally well.
Cons: Like most technology industries, supporting a 24/7 network means being on call from time to time.

Review Title: Great experience and made life long friends along the way
Pros: The people I worked with. Be prepared to work hard but have fun at the same time. I worked at Playstation for about 5 years and I grew professionally and personally at this company. The pay was OK but there are plenty of benefits when working for a company like this. They have a great campus and the location is set not to far from the San Francisco airport.
Cons: There are some office politics that go on here. And I did see and experience some shady moves happen. But in a company or organization you will see it.

Pros: Great products, great employee interaction, respect of consumers. In a very competitive market, SCEA stood apart by not bowing to the "easy route". Management was willing to stick to plan even when it appeared things were not going well. Most times, in the end, management was right and it was good to be part of it.
Cons: Political system for promotions or job assignments. Mostly based on who you knew or were friendly with. Mid-level management would attack peers considered rivals for time, attention, or job opportunities.

Review Title: Not living up to its potential
Pros: The Sony PlayStation network is huge network, presenting many challenging engineering problems. Coworkers are a great bunch of people who, while very diverse, get along well and are respectful of each other. There's always a fun social event to participate in. Benefits are pretty good (I don't know what other companies are offering but I've been happy with the benefits).
Cons: Over the past three years, the San Diego office has seen a new senior VP, two additional VPs, multiple directors and senior architects and managers all come in from the same company (Intuit). At the same time, the existing senior Sony people have been squeezed out, quietly encouraged to leave, or just fired. No one from the original Sony Network San Diego in any position of responsibility and no one from the original Sony days has been promoted. There have been many new senior level positions filled, but none from within the company. Some have been given new titles, but no real promotions. Existing engineers have not been allowed to participate in the technical direction of the network. They are seen as hindrances and not as contributors. A closed environment of fear and distrust has been created where people cannot question direction or voice honest opinions.
