It's a dreary engineering environment lacking in excitement or peer collaboration.

Pros: The people you work with are amazing. Arguably the best part about working here. The benefits are also top notch if you're a full time employee.
Cons: Leadership lacks diversity. Heads are all older white males with the exception of 1 new executive hire. There's little opportunities for women here due to the ratio differences. During fiscal budget planning or quarterly budget planning, employees are on their toes because not only are there budget cuts, but that usually means the cuts will be coming from headcount. Expect surprise lay offs.

Pros: The company offers great benefits and is flexible when it comes to maintaining a good work-life balance. Employees are friendly and open-minded and there is a solid sense of community.
Cons: Lots of office politics. Very ageist organization. Promotions go to friends or connections. Lower-level employees do the bulk of the work while senior leadership take credit and keep getting promoted. Not much room for innovation and independent thought. A great place for followers, not so much for people who want to effect real change.

Pros: Company has a great environment and work atmosphere ; People all around are friendly. Playstation has an amazing campus in San Mateo and throughout the summer there were a few events that were extremely fun.
Cons: The company has a lot of people who have been there for a long period of time , these individuals are occupying management positions that could be filled up with fresh blood , there aren't many opportunities to grow within the company. Compensation is very low , specially considering the location of Playstation's headquarter.

Pros: Great canteen -Decent Pay -relaxed working environment
Cons: -Overuse of contractors with refusal to grant stable permanent positions with inferred benefits - Drink/sleep with the boss to get anywhere - it's a bit of an old boys club. - Expected to come into the office on Xmas day - Terrible work-life balance of hours between 8AM - 11PM for frontline contractors - Management are old-school and refuse to keep up with the times - Huge lack of communication between various areas of the business. - Complaints about sexual harassment are mostly ignored by HR/ Management until volume of complaints is too high

Pros: Company culture is diversified and excellent with people from all parts of the world Environment and colleagues are great with relationship with business areas when defining projects Challenging projects due to lack of integration between the platforms used on the business applications Good benefits, from subsidized canteen and bar to discount on products, plus an excellent holiday allowance Senior Management is usually accessible and line managers are flexible with estimates and open for ideas on how to better solve a problem
Cons: Low salary Long time for plans to kick-off No chance of career progression, even you are good and hard worker Lack of commitment from some colleagues and areas Counterproductive process to get small things done All this cause a high turnover which impacts further the plans made

Pros: good work-life balance, great bonuses at year end, best PTO policy & the number of days I have ever come across, fun people to work!
Cons: only get promoted or moved to a new role if an employee leaves the position; depending on the manager you work for, they truly are interested in your growth and knowledge enhancement

Pros: Not a lot of top-down management pressure A lot of flexibility in how you get your job done Good pay Great benefits Generally a good team culture
Cons: Big company, so politics abound Hard to ferret out what's really going on unless you're part of the "favored" group of individuals that knows all the secrets

Pros: many opportunities to learn new things, trainings, conferences - Diverse technology also encourages people to learn and master new skills - Good benefits - Talented people - Friendly atmosphere
Cons: - Company carries the baggage from 10-15 years ago: departmental silos, IT vs Dev, slow to react to new technologies - sub-par management on all levels: micromanagement, lack of transparency, say one thing-do something else, favoritism, personal preferences - talented employees were forced out because they didn't submit to their poorly performing superiors

Review Title: One of the best game studios to work for in Los Angeles
Pros: AAA Quality Projects Competitive Benefits Unique Work Environment Encourages Creativity More Control of your tasks and creations
Cons: Not much room for personal growth, the studio is very large . It is not clear how certain individuals are promoted when comparing the amount of contributions other developers bring the studio. Not much of an effort has been made to solidify art direction. Lack of direction is also the result of allowing too much free will.

Review Title: Good company philosophy -- poorly vetted, hostile management
Pros: Many good people in the organization from diverse backgrounds; on-premises health club and cafe; hot food is available almost all day. Easy parking, safe work location.
Cons: Where do I begin? The hostility in this place is rampant. It exists at all levels, including the administration. Legacy employees live in silos and treat new employees with utter disdain. On the platform engineering side, the formerly-Intuit management solution to growth is to stack layers and layers of management between themselves and the worker bees. This is offset somewhat by the Japanese philosophy of owning the outcome - they force managers to rotate on-call; eating their own dog-food, so to speak. Instead of studying and refining current tools and processes, they create a new management position to address a shortcoming. Right now I have four managers between myself and a director. We have three engineers and one manager in my group. That's one manager for three people! Forget about fair consideration for a job. Some managers post jobs only as a necessary requirement, but could care less about outside candidates. I've seen highly qualified candidates completely overlooked because the hiring manager wanted to give that job to an old colleague or friend. If outside applicants had any idea, they probably wouldn't apply. Why should they? They'll likely get other offers before Sony gives them a chance. I can go on and on, -- the micro-managing, the meaningless gestures of generosity, the lack of coordination and standardization, etc., but I won't. But let me say this... if you apply at the Sony Taleo web site, and someday you get an email from Sony, be wary. The only reason why they would seem eager to hire anyone is to fill in a position that is badly understaffed. You'll get quickly hired thrown right into the fire, without even a semblance of proper guidance. Then what? Before you know it, you're stuck in a lousy job. And don't let them offer you a bonus with your salary negotiations. It's totally bogus. Unless you work 12 hour days and weekends and nights, you won't see squat for a bonus. I paid in blood, sweat and tears for this company, working weekends and nights and early mornings, only to be "rewarded" with a bonus that was a fraction of what was due. Sony pays out very little in bonuses even though the platform is making almost $8 billion this year alone! Over 1000 people work their butts off at SNEI to guarantee this 24/7/365 revenue stream for Sony, and for them to turn around and pay out a tiny fraction as a bonus is beyond insulting. It's a slap in the face. Don't waste your time with Sony Network Entertainment. Between the hostility, layers and layers of inept management, long, long hours and sheisty bonus payouts, there's very little reason to want to join this company. Which is too bad because I find the Japanese principals I work with --nationals from Japan-- to be wonderful people with honest and kind intentions. They're polite, generous, understanding, forgiving to a reasonable degree, and eager to come up with cool stuff, like the Playstation Network. It's the middle and upper management from the US and elsewhere that are ruining things for SNEI. This could be a much strong and more profitable company if it weren't for these management problems.

Pros: The people, the technology, the environment, the cool factor of working at PlayStation, the fact that you work at a company that has customers who are not just customers they are fans! The executives are actually really cool people who do not sit on a pedestal. In fact, all of the management team and all of the individual contributors are genuinely sincere people who really care about the product and that's an amazing thing. The VPs and SVPs are incredible, approachable, knowledgeable, thoughtful and caring about the fans first. They practice what they preach for sure when it comes to being the best place to play (and work!) It's really an incredible place to work for so many reasons. The benefits and the perks and everything, I won't even describe because they're what you would expect… Simply amazing. It is definitely the coolest place I've ever worked and that's a high bar. There are so many great things to say about this company that I would probably spend the next hour writing them but I don't know if anyone would ever read all the amazing things I could say.
Cons: No clue how they ever delivered any product in the 20+ years before I got there. The process, or processes, are a total mess. No one business unit has any of the same or even similar processes - even with in the same business unit. Remember now, I am giving a four star review here because it is truly a pleasure to work there. It would be a 5 Star review....But, there are some serious deficiencies in how the company operates that have been solved at software and hardware companies years and years ago. Generally speaking, there aren't many egos to deal with but, there are a few and most of those come from the newer individual contributors, not the management team. Thankfully for the customers, a.k.a. fans, they make billions of dollars and can afford to make billions of mistakes and still deliver consistently. It's a crazy mystery I'll never understand but it does actually work I guess. The fact that no one knows who does what is the biggest challenge. Figuring out what people do in the company, because no one actually seems to know and I'm talking about people who have been there for years and years is amazingly difficult. AMAZINGLY DIFFICULT.

Review Title: Changes are not for the better
Pros: - Competitive and plentiful benefits - Up to 3.5% matching for 401K - Easy going immediate coworkers - Flexibility of schedule from immediate management - Frequently Giveaways and Campus events - Free Game Content for select teams - Easy Parking - Lots of love for brand culture
Cons: lots of critical scrutiny from Upper non-US based management - lower than average wages for many positions - many slacker teams - Not much visibility with The frequent reorganizations until after The fact - poor Career progression paths

Review Title: Tremendous innovation and hard work on the part of the team
Pros: Start-up culture, agile development, progressive technology, willingness to try new things to make the overall product better. Has a great product and is changing the gaming industry. Lots of potential to leverage the platform for other areas of growth. Eagerness on the part of management for associates to take on new roles and step into the green field.
Cons: A few too many "Chefs" created blurred roles at the top of the house. Long hours due to the start-up nature of the company. Limited budgets created the temptation to build solutions that they might be able to otherwise buy to shorten cycle times and deploy a better solution.

Review Title: I owe my career to PlayStation!
Pros: The environment was friendly and casual. You could be yourself--piercings, tattoos, colored hair. The health and medical benefits were outstanding. Schedule was quite relaxed, so a good work/life balance was possible.
Cons: Things moved slowly. Even though there was no dress code, in certain business units there was the feeling you were judged by appearance. Gossip and politics weren't out of control, but they were definitely there.

Review Title: Great company, middle management could be better.
Pros: Great corporate atmosphere, company is doing well, top leaders are visionaries. Some of the smartest people I've known.
Cons: Some groups have been growing, which is good, but new hires in the last couple years at the director level have been poor at best. Very political with little accountability or vision. If you end up reporting to such a person, be cautious.

Pros: Diverse management and colleagues Better than average benefits and pay Management has a clear focused long term goal Unlike rest of Sony, flat organization (though its being challenged)
Cons: Grew a little too fast As the company grows within Sony, we are moving away from the flat organization HR and management has been focused on employee quantity for far too long. Too slow to invest on employee quality.

Review Title: Great place to work at a local level, difficult as you start dealing with the broader organization
Pros: Smart people driven to deliver. It's a fun place to work and spend your day. Compensation is also in the appropriate range so it's a nice gig.
Cons: Lack of strong vision and decision making makes for challenging projects and nebulous goals. Many areas could be exploited it we moved aggressively with purpose. Instead we seem to meander into our destination and it's frequently not as good a solution as we could have had with strong leadership.

Pros: very Talented, capable people - tasks are Challenging, Good place to learn for a short time
Cons: - Terrible micromanagement - people are overworked; the Japanese work culture requires you to stay in the office longer than that is usual in the American work culture - everybody keeps a lot of distance, people don't usually talk to each other; they go to the office, work and go home; period - compensation varies widely based on who is the closest to the management - management has the technical abilities to lead, however completely lacks people management skills - no career opportunities; career development completely depends on friendship with the management - the HR is incompetent Avoid at all cost.

Pros: There is no more passionate group of collaborators about PlayStation who take ownership of issues and share solutions with team members. Management gives individual contributors the autonomy to identify, present a solution, deploy and manage programs.
Cons: Bandwidth is stretched tight as there is always more work than there are teammates. As there is no PMO, it is common to deploy projects with insufficient testing with an assumption the issues would be fixed later. The benefit package is good, but pay is below industry average.

Review Title: Great place to work with smart and fun people all around
Pros: Friendliness, work-life balance and very collaborative cross-functional env. Very goal and project oriented group and employees shared responsibilities of supporting all critical systems and business user can always count on the IT group. Lots of fun activities and goodies and very often surrounded by enthusiastic new title or product releases excitements and thus promoted a very positive and thriving corporate culture of which enabled forwarding thinking and cutting edge and new product market direction strategic planning.
Cons: Career advancement and growth can be more defined within the core group. Overall company goals could be funneled down to individual department and contributor's goals for common achievements.

Pros: Talented, caring people. Wide array of technical and non-technical roles. Global organization. Exciting industry (video games and entertainment), with exciting products. Fair salaries, bonus, and even severance. Strong market share after launching PlayStation 4.
Cons: Heavily contracting staff in World Wide Studios (WWS), many teams are now half their original size. Executive leadership is not always strategic, and decisions are made slowly. Accountability is poorly maintained in most organizations, and often is culturally set by specific leaders throughout the various groups. Many folks are coasting (which impacts high-potentials/strong performers and team success potential); most global teams are silo'd, and employees are less of a priority/focus and poorly celebrated (besides shallow perks like free and discounted games).

Review Title: Good place to learn a few things, but you'll get itchy feet if you want a more dynamic environment
Pros: Visibility on a lot of projects that are eagerly awaited by Joe Public Some brilliant people to learn from Good company to have on CV
Cons: A LOT of bureacracy A lot of people who have been there for a LONG time, and just plod along Pay is under industry standard, but getting better

Review Title: Good place to work but pay not great
Pros: Sony is a good place to work however things can move very slowly as management seem reluctant to make decisions
Cons: Things can sometimes move very slowly, and there can be lots of red tape. The worst thing is the pay is way below industry standards. There are also lots of little clicks if your not in your out.

Review Title: Good place to work if you are not at base level.
Pros: Brilliant Human resources, good working environment, fun place to work, good benefits, (free games, work parties/social events)
Cons: Hard to progress due to internal politics, wages are lower than that of competitors. Those in lower positions aren't treated as well as they should. Bonus scales are pretty low. Too many middle managers. Certifiable training courses are barely available for non-managers.

Pros: Surrounded by approachable people willing to help you learn anything - Integrated into a working development team - being proactive is welcomed and rewarded - Generate a ton of Great references, and if you standout, they remember when It comes Hiring time - PlayStation culture is Great if you are into video games and stuff
Cons: - Maybe not the most likely internship to land you a permanent job, but they're pretty clear about that upfront (I still ended up with a contract job and eventually a permanent job)

Review Title: Be ready to deal with excessive levels of management and red tape, all for wages which are far below industry standards.
Pros: Good offices, good location. Great projects to work on that genuinely have an impact on many many people. Other engineers can be great to work with.
Cons: Salary Biggest con about this company is the salaries they pay. In general they will greatly underpay it's employees because they are working for 'Sony'. And, as HR and many managers will phrase it, that privilege equates to lesser pay. It can take years of bonuses and wage increments for ones yearly pay to match what you'd get elsewhere in the same industry at far, far smaller organisations. This is particularly true for mid-level/senior engineers and employees in the lower levels of the archaic hierarchy who have little management influence in their day-to-day roles. Good pay if your a manager though. Management/Culture This is arguably what destroys employee dissatisfaction most within the organisation/department. Even more so within its own R&D department. This is entirely dependent on who your manager is, so this particular negative applies to my own department and some of the teams I worked with rather than the whole organisation. Management is filled with stagnated and decade-old middle managers (and in my particular case) who did very little to no actual work outside of organizing meetings and providing already-clear direction. Little to absolutely no room for personal growth. My own manager implemented absurdly authoritarian-like methods and checks to ensure engineers were hitting targets and not missing deadlines (e.g filling out detailed excel 'time-sheets' submitted weekly). Managers are never questioned as it is believed their experience equates to infallibility, and when problems do arise blame is quickly shifted beneath them when possible, or otherwise ignored and hushed when fingers cannot be easily pointed down the assembly line. This fostered an environment within engineering teams where we had to constantly proclaim and prove what we were doing. Animosity easily developed between co-workers new or old because of this and would quickly look for excuses or throw others under the bus to shift accountability. E.g: Managment: You reported in the time sheet you coded X feature, which took you Y hours, and Z lines of code (yes they count lines of code). This is bad it should have only taken you minimum X-6 hours (arbitrary estimation with little consideration of actual engineering challenges). Why are you under-performing? Person: I did what I could under the restrictions of teammate A not doing Task Con time, also blame this tool was broken and XYZ teams did not communicate and deliver, etc etc. I hope things have changed since I left because in particular one team at SCEE R&D has extremely high employee turnover for many years. Yet everyone seemed to casually ignore that perhaps the all-wise manager running the team and their methods were the actual cause of engineers leaving every 1-2 years.

Review Title: good company to get experience in, growth industry
Pros: good for resume. experience in the gaming industry. The company has grown very fast so intercommunications are a little slow and organizational stuff is hard to organize. It takes a lot of time to get projects approved, and sometimes they get killled - i guess all big companies are similar.
Cons: big company downsides, nothing unsual. Too many discussions with all company branches, a lot of time wated on talking about projects instead of just doing them. Sony's different companies don't talk to each other a lot, this is improving a lot in the last 2 years, and might make sony a much better place to work in.

Pros: There are great health benefits, great relationships, great environment, easy going
Cons: There are lots of groups that don't know what they are doing. There is really no managing skills, over worked, your job title isnt your only job. You feel like you are doing other peoples jobs.

Review Title: Great company for benefits not so much for job stability and security recently
Pros: Excellent benefits including 401k matching, very competitive number of paid holidays and paid time off, multiple fun work events throughout the year, great health insurance benefits, on-site gym and pool access along with free fitness classes.
Cons: Job stability and security has been on the decline do to a lot of recent corporate restructuring. Management is not always clear and open with the direction of the company and how that impacts current employees.

Pros: At Bend Studio, you work with some of the most talented people in the industry. Everyone is extremely motivated to produce their best work possible. They really push the limits as to what can and can't be done. If you're an outdoorsy person, the location is a huge plus. Plenty of hiking, mountain biking, camping minutes from the city limits. And if the snow's good, Mt Bachelor's only a 20-30 min drive.
Cons: It's the only entertainment company in Bend. So if by chance you end up looking for other work, you'll have to head north to Portland or Seattle, or obviously South towards the Bay Area or Socal.

Pros: Work on games enjoyed by millions of people. Flexible hours and attire (like holy Australian Nightmare you wouldn't believe the way we dress for work). Excellent facilities with numerous amenities (gym, pool, aerobics, etc.)
Cons: Our culture is heavily siloed and relies on ad-hoc individual contributions. There is a very need-to-know culture of secrecy around almost everything. I don't think anyone has spent any time developing and promoting wholesome institutional habits. So, everything falls on the shoulders of individuals and when they leave that bit of institutional knowledge inevitably goes with them.

Review Title: Business is Business at Employees expense
Pros: Good while it lasts, finally got 8 hours off every month PTO only to get laid off.
Cons: Employees are tools, that is all. Local Management more so. Jobs posted should have been filled long ago but no one is qualified to hire so they fall back on Temps or worse Interns. Business suffers and politics says all is well until the next lay off hits. Walked out whole Department midday, not allowed to say goodbye or get a soda. They do Fed-Ex your personal property at least.

Pros: The food, coffee, and special events.
Cons: Senior management is negative and puts others down as if it's a game. This demeaning attitude is also reflected in people who work closely with management. You're constantly criticized by others and never given support/encouragement. This was a regular complaint I heard from peers. You would constantly hear employees in Procurement and Project Management complaining about how stressed they were. The managers are incompetent and promoted without any experience in their field, with bunk degrees (DeVry, Phoenix, etc.). They also hire family members without experience in their field. This makes it difficult for anyone with actual qualifications to work effectively and make improvements. Many employees are incompetent and don't reply to emails or phone calls.

Review Title: A great company with way too much drama
Pros: Great business model/framework, reasonable workload.
Cons: Drama drama drama: Ever changing upper management and shuffle around people at regular basis; A few groupies that hard to work with or talk with; Incompetent middle management walk around like HR nightmares....

Pros: - I've interned for three other companies, and the PlayStation one was by far the best - Intern and company events are very fun - Learning new technologies outside of class with smart people - Amazing perks - Treated as a full time employee - Growing company with lots of opportunities
Cons: - This year's response times to possible full time conversion were slower but was mainly due to the merge - Communication with students who were graduating in the immediate future while they wait for a response would have been appreciated

Review Title: The Best Job I Ever Had
Pros: I was a technical documentation manager and website producer - working with all of Sony's Playstation Studios around the world. Travelled to visit studios in the US, in Europe, and in Japan. I developed media and themes for Sony's internal developer conference, and managed posting conference sessions on the internal website for studios to share. Best job of my career - my boss gave me freedom to define my role as I thought it should be done.
Cons: All big companies have a fundamental flaw: lack of coordination among various disbursed groups. I learned to live with that in my 30+ year career in software development.

Pros: Atmosphere is low stress, people are great and the comp is decent. Most senior management are Sony lifers and not very brilliant or inspirational. If you like to game and be part of the industry you'll get some great perks in marketing, sales or development.
Cons: Senior managers are yes men and will do anything to keep their cushy positions. The top management is a full time internal PR machine.

Pros: Apart from global brand recognition...there are no pros to working here. Oh wait...discounts on video games, that was cool...better if they were free though!
Cons: -Senior management that is not only incompetent, but insane. They seem to pick their sr mgt based on: nepotism, BS skills, or whoever can manage to wait it out there.....15+ years. Imagine that! -No real career advancement path. -Complete lack of communication from Japan about company changes, product development...their employees find out from the media.

Review Title: Awesome CEO - Awesome place to work - Awesome campus
Pros: Awesome CEO - Awesome place to work - Awesome People - Awesome campus - Awesome Culture - Awesome initiatives
Cons: Extremely poor middle management Senior Director level, Head of organization. Lack of accountability and competence. Several others....

Review Title: It's not a culture for everyone
Pros: Benefits are great as far as San Diego employers go. They try to compete with Silicon Valley companies on this front. Pay is generous for the area, as far as I can tell. They are definitely willing to pay out for talent. There's a nice cafeteria on the 11th floor, where you can occasionally get an ocean view. There are also many fun activities for employees throughout the year: take your child to work day, happy hours, nice holiday party, video games, off campus events, etc.
Cons: Much of this is probably dependent on the team you are a part of. In fact that itself is a major con. The teams are generally very siloed. There is not a lot of communication across teams on the individual contributor level. The management style is very top-down. They pretend to be agile by implementing SAFe, but SAFe is a little too structured and too pre-planned to really be considered agile. The company is very inefficient. Most of the teams at the San Diego location are there to support infrastructure in some form or fashion, but yet there are always outages. The company would do well to outsource the infrastructure support and hosting to a vendor and focus on developing services. There are also cultural inefficiencies. For those that are unlucky enough to have a team with mostly Japanese management, you had better learn Japanese or else you can expect not to be included in any of the decision making process. There is an obvious divide in business culture: Japanese and everyone else. They do a lot to take care of employees (see the pros) but the management style and the inefficiencies just make you not care to try. There is such a culture of mediocrity, and so much of the work seems like work for the sake of work. If you are close to retirement age and looking for a place to just coast for the last few years, there is probably a position here where you can give minimal effort and not get a lot of grief for it.

Review Title: Low $$ and toxic management not worth the Fun Culture and Great staff.
Pros: Fun Culture, Great People , MD who was passionate about the Brand. Social events and incentives + benefits great. Sales Team leadership was great.
Cons: Salary not competitive, OLD systems and technology, No direction from direct management, MD who lived and breathed the brand and cared about everyone was let go after launching the business 20+ years ago. Heartless. Collaboration between departments is not encouraged. Absolute boys club, no female managers. My manager would pile work on top of me even though i was struggling and concerns were laughed off.

Pros: Plenty of company vacation days; Discounted company products
Cons: Boys club; Luck is essential to have career growth here; Top-down performance review only - manager has unlimited power; Highly UNcompetitive in salary and bonus; No stock option; Some team encourages bad work-life-balance; Lots of bureaucracy and office politics

Review Title: My experience, and for a few others
Pros: A gateway into other more permanent opportunities. Certainly gave me the power to seek something else after my experience. I made a few nice friends there.
Cons: Toxic Environment, Poor Training, Favouritism, Lack of Opportunities. People are toxic to one another and step over each other for permanent positions. God forbid you actually get an interview, if youre not liked even with a lot of experience and knowledge, you wont be getting the job. Myself and a few other colleagues experienced the poor treatment to a few of us. This usually happened when they were thinking about letting us go just before our 2 years of service under the Yoh contract. Please get rid of agencies and begin to hire your QA staff permanently. The place is too toxic with everyone too scared to be let go, and so resort to trying to obtain a permanent position in any way that they can. Even if they try, if they arent very popular or dont live in Liverpool you can bet 100% theyll be ignored. Even if theyre hardworking. Seniors do more than the managers, or so thats how it appeared to me. People always left continously due to feeling underappreciated especially since the start of the pandemic. Where are the thank yous, gifts, and free PS5s which you gave to permanent Sony staff but not Yoh? Oh yes, and half-days, sick pay. Yoh get none of it, just 10p soda cans and a free game once a year. Its not enough for all the hours and effort we put in for you. Theyll get rid of you if you arent pulling your weight, or if you are will move you from title to title with no explanation making the experience harder. Great for CV, but not for work relationships and a sense of overall purpose there. Expect your colleagues to treat you as someone under them; acting like your boss. These are usually the ones who are trying to become a senior and unfortunately it always works. Theyll be horrible and get thanked for it. Like huh? Oh, I had 1 performance review from Yoh after 2 years and it lasted 10 minutes. Thats all I get? Thankfully I handed in my notice whilst being accepted into a studio, and I couldnt be more happier. The new place is much more welcoming, and actually cares about my progress. So please, if youre under a temporary contract treat it as temporary and dont attempt to stay. Unless you have old friends there, which a lot of them did. Filling the whole place with nepotism. If you live outside the area, your chances are much lower. Good luck. But I would avoid if I were you.

Pros: Brand recognition, relatively competitive benefits package, office facilities were adequate for an office of this size, some SCEA perks were nice due to affiliation with Sony. Some very talented individuals within the organization motivated to doing great things.
Cons: Too much office politics, constant dealings with emotional, irrational management. Cannot get ahead unless in bed (literally) with management, quid pro quo. Low morale. Too many Sony "lifers" in the organization more interested in protecting their position rather than push interesting ideas. Too much inertia and inflexible due to the many layers of management and red tape.

Review Title: On the verge of greatness ... if they can overcome some serious issues
Pros: A thrilling opportunity to work on some of the most exciting brands in consumer technology. A group of highly creative and talented individuals passionate about the product and their roles. The company is always looking to challenge the status quo with campaigns and events to keep the brand on top.
Cons: Challenges with talent development and retention. Pay is well below average for other tech companies. Promotions and growth is challenging and met with unnecessary bureaucracy and politics. Achievements often go overlooked and unrecognized. Lack of transparency and communications within and between teams.

Pros: Great brand, company culture is casual, lots always going on with new offerings.
Cons: Too many politics based on peoples personality. Lots of talking behind peoples backs, whispering colleagues. Too many "stuck" employees just doing the basics to get them through the day. Not enough promotional opportunities to progress people quickly to where they develop to be. Instead they look to jump ship to higher level opportunities.

Review Title: Do not work here unless you are a geek gamers.
Pros: -good discounts on first party products with the exception of hardware -decently large company so you're bound to meet someone you like -expectations are not too high for employee performance, if you are a decently smart person you can pretty much flat by forever and not worry about getting let go(if that is the type of career you want), leading the the number of incompetent employees who have been around for 5-10 years. however this does not take into account the random employee layoffs due to poor Sony (parent organization) performance
Cons: -In the marketing organization, hiring is essentially based on your knowledge of the gaming industry, hence I was surrounded by a lot of incompetent colleagues who just know the industry very well. It was ridiculous some of the things I had to teach people who had 5+ years experience. -Management operates in a black box - very little transparency of where the company is headed or what is going on -You are surrounded by a lot of gamer geeks who know little of anything but gaming. Very knowledgeable on the topic but have little knowledge on other topics -Very bureaucratic and slow organization. Lots of work is done just for the sake of doing the work and half the reports and analysis created is not utilized and is truly a waste of time -They try very hard to portray themselves as a fun tech/gaming company, but in reality the organization is structured like a old slow company, it's just that folks will sit and play games so they think it is start-up like -Very slow and hard to get promoted. Lots of the incompetent gamers who have worked very hard to get into this company never leave, hence it's very hard to move up as openings rarely present themselves. This company does nor necessarily promote based on performance. -People seem to get promoted based on amount time in company as opposed to performance. Even someone was performing way beyond expectations won't get a promotion because "it has only been 2 years since you joined" -Review process is really a joke - it's literally a check of the box, management is very weak in this department and does not do anything to develop employees -This company lends itself to brown nosing. Sycophants do very well in this company even if their performance is lacking. -Non one in the marketing organization does their own work. They ask certain support/analytics teams and external vendors to essentially do all the heavy lifting and just package everything and present it to management as their own. -Pay is okay at entry level - because you start as hourly - this makes your salary pretty competitive, but once promoted, your salary will take a hit because you are no longer hourly

Pros: - 1 week off for Xmas & NY @ EOY - Gym free to all F/T employees on new campus - Access to free games - etc...
Cons: Can be overworked in order to make ends meet - low base Pay compared to most tech companies in The bay area

Review Title: Fun environment but pay has something to be desired
Pros: Environment is fun even when you're working hard.
Cons: Pay is not competitive for the Bay Area. Promotions are hard to come by as the opportunities can be limited in some departments.

Review Title: Poor Middle Management, No Career Advancement
Pros: Great benefits and salary is reasonable - Bagels and pastries on Friday - smart and reliable engineers - Diverse environment - Sony name reference on resume
Cons: middle management micro-managing, some very rude, very impersonal - no work-life balance - Unless you become friend with supervisor, you are stuck - lots of office Politics - Unfair working environment, some slackers

Review Title: Lots of cool stuff, but mired in bureaucracy
Pros: * Company loves innovation * Diverse * Welcoming culture * You get to work on products people get excited about
Cons: * Bureaucracy * Innovation gets choked out by process * Spends so much time reinventing itself that it can't execute on the basics * Career success depends on being on being on the right projects more than actual effort

Review Title: Mostly a great place to work
Pros: Salary, work-life balance, opportunity to grow if you are motivated, PERKS, free stuff, connection to a great product, central location, lots of free food. Ability to work with new technologies if you can prove why its better, not just because its new.
Cons: Bad developers are not let go, super-tight development schedule does not leave enough time for proper design, high-turn over of good developers.

Pros: SNEI, SCEA, and SCEE combined into SIE in 2016 after moving their HQ to San Mateo from Los Angeles in 2014. PSN is so profitable, particularly with PS+ their PSN subscription service, that every action is predicated on how much revenue gets sent back to Japan to invest in retooling SonyMobile and SonyElectronics, both in the toilet for years. On top of this the San Diego computer and warehouse effort is being shut down without anyone there knowing it's happening other than the new Intuit management brought in during 2015. The talent who realized this have all left, or they've gotten rid of their most senior staff by "abolishing their jobs (code for laying off highly-paid professionals they know will resist their new "QuickAndDirty" #FauxAgile approach), and the lower-paid-less-experienced replacements are managing to introduce more outages than fewer. Outages will be the ONLY driver of churn once PS4 and XBox put their proprietary prowess on the cloud , relieving them of a $400 chunk of plastic and iron sitting on your shelf today. When this occurs, PSN's propensity to "go down" due to sloppy code, an out of control codebase, multiple copies of their database in multiple locations across the globe, and poor security will eventually tilt in Xbox's failure. Sony's only hope for market dominance will then rely on a monopoly of critical game titles, the lone three of #GTA, FIFASoccer, and WorldOfWarcraft already comprising the lion's share of their total revenue including music-video-game-and-SonyVueTV.! Once a great place to innovate, it's now a great place to go lose your capacity to work anywhere else as old-timey technology like Oracle RDBMS and clones of RDBMS' functioning in under-horsed Hadoop platforms.
Cons: inability to move toward higher technology tools trapping professional staff in a cycle of future unemployability.

Pros: Lots to do. Some great Talent and management is trying to make positive changes to the business. Most of the executive team have been with the company a long time and have industry experience
Cons: Old guard management with a couple of exceptions. What changes are being done can be considered questionable. Not many perks. Not much recognition. Slow to make decisions.

Pros: The people you work with are amazing. Innovated, and hardworking. It's casual attire which is awesome! Bonuses are freaking awesome!!!
Cons: it can be very hard to move up in the company. You probably stay an individual contributor your whole career. So just be prepared for that.

Review Title: Culture is Different at Each Office
Pros: The San Francisco office definitely has a little more of a start-up feel (things are a little more agile), but with a strong financial backing. The politics are not bad, and everyone seems to work well with each other.
Cons: However, there are some bureaucracies you have to deal with because Sony is a very big company. Departments which service employess (such as IT help desk and HR) are not very friendly at the SF office.

Pros: Relaxed working environment, smart people, good yearly bonus, a fast growing company.
Cons: Lags other tech companies in terms of salary. A lot of the upper management came directly from Intuit and feels a bit like they were just handed positions with no regard for their skillsets. A lot of these upper managers lack a good long term vision.

Pros: It's really great! Great pay, mostly cool coworkers and direct reports. They work hard to create a really fun culture. I'm managing back end teams right now, so I don't even have regular releases or have to manage in flight pages and teams. I've never been less stressed in my life.
Cons: Not alot of opportunity. Seem to be sort of in a career eddy where I don't feel alot of upward momentum, but I'm at peace with that for the moment. Most who are leaving are getting paid elsewhere so there's a little fear of missing out (FOMO).

Pros: Lots of passion & enthusiasm. Potentially some great opportunities to work with some really talented people who are trying to create what could be a phenomenal product.
Cons: Disorganization, in fighting and an overall lack of a holistic product vision create a lot of redundancy and waste. Company culture and facilities are lacking and the work life balance need some work.

Review Title: No recognition for performance, lack of support for growth, not a team environment
Pros: High Brand, some great people and projects. Product development organization is much better run than the corporate side.
Cons: Lack of real vision from executive team. Executives are self serving, afraid of talent. Too many junior employees compared to senior management. Infrastructure and process is lacking.

Review Title: Fun and professionally stimulating place to work
Pros: People, working conditions, relaxed environment, plenty of excellent people in Senior Management, Playstation makes you feel passionate about the brand
Cons: SCEE and SNEE segregation (very distant worlds). No 3rd party games allocation. Questionable pricing strategies.

Pros: If you're a gamer, tons of free stuff and access to things that are interesting to you. If you're not a gamer... well...
Cons: Technology, network and features are so far behind the competition and management can't figure out how to capitalize on a huge PlayStation audience that is willing to pay for quality.

Review Title: Great People (for the most part) but the politics are awful
Pros: Talented, passionate, driven people FUN atmosphere and culture Awesome content Opportunities to travel internationally
Cons: Internal politics, both within a single Sony division and among the sister Sony companies makes everything take forever, contentious, and decisions are made for political expediency vs. what's best. No work life balance to speak of

Review Title: Great brand to work for, poorly managed
Pros: Relaxed environment - Nice offices, Central location (if you like Central London) - Informal dress code
Cons: - Lack of opportunity to grow - Management is very much a 'boys club', with perks or benefits only going to select few usually male employees - Salary is significantly lower than market value - Management concerned with cutting budgets, rather than spending it on their team development, morale and salaries

Pros: Great work life balance, if you focus on it Mostly amazing, hard working, smart folks A strong focus (the TPR department) on mental health of their workers and external partner happiness Great benefits Strong leadership from the very top, enthusiasm and love for games and for what we do
Cons: Slow moving, but that's typical of a large company A few people who are just in it for the paycheck but that is rare

Pros: Fast pace work environment due to competitive game industry and new technology result in many opportunities for individual and career growth.
Cons: HR and other corporate support groups and Sr Mgmt are not as much in line with the game side of the business and seem unable to keep pace with work environment changes and strain to provide proper support.

Pros: Fun and exciting environment. Producing products with end user recognition and appreciation. Hard working and passionate colleagues.
Cons: Poor and uncommunicative upper management (director level and above). Slow career progression. Still disconnects and silos between groups in SCEA and with other Sony divisions.

Review Title: Wonderful atmosphere, but management should be more proactive
Pros: Excellent products, genuine concern, effort and desire to make our products the best in the industry. Lots of opportunity to work with employees at every level. No formality or rigidity, very congenial atmosphere. Many really smart colleagues.
Cons: Some members of senior management are entrenched and distracted or otherwise insufficiently responsive to important issues as they arise. Payroll, finance and accounting systems are overly labor-intensive and are highly dysfunctional.

Review Title: A Good and Fun Place to Work
Pros: Fun industry and the ability to feel a part of the product. Good inter-functional cooperation, for the most part enables one to succeed on projects that require cross-functional participation.
Cons: Development costs have dramatically increased, making it ever more difficult to product profitable games which leads to a tendency to make "safe" bets (sequels, etc), which takes away some of the fun in creativity.

Pros: It's a good place to work, and has excellent time off policies for that work/life balance. People are usually friendly and tend to help each other when needed. Strong brand name makes me feel proud to be at SCEA.
Cons: There's an increasing sense of political warefare. Management always reward their friends and don't appreciate the people underneath them. It can be unfair at times.

Review Title: A lot of opportunity for growth
Pros: Tons of work perks, great, young people and collaborative atmosphere. Working for SNEI is like working for a start-up company with a backing of a tech giant. Lots of opportunities to grow if you work hard.
Cons: Behind in technological innovations. There is a desperate need for different divisions of Sony to work better together for unified user experience and for innovation.

Pros: Very positive work place with nice and friendly people. Summer intern program is excellent. Learned lot of things from senior engineers and managers, got a chance to work on innovative projects. Exposure to senior members through speaker series. Competitive Salary. Fun events. This is a great place to start your career.
Cons: Nothing as of now :)

Review Title: Some great people slow moving to catch up
Pros: Some groups are full of creative hardworking folks, but it varies from group to group. Overall being part of the video game industry is fun
Cons: SIlo'd groups, company is slow to change and share information. A lot of tenured people who are going through the motions, but new people as have a problem adjusting causing strife

Review Title: A good opportunity to be in the video game industry
Pros: #ERROR!
Cons: - Very big entity with the "corporate" and "bureaucratic" attributes you might expect - Changes come slowly, if at all - Poor performing staff seem to remain in roles for too long (incl. management)

Pros: The leaders are loyal, the employees love games and the campus is pretty sweet. Pay is okay, and no stock upside, but a very good base and always a good bonus if you have a good review.
Cons: It always feels like the management is a matrix. Decisions are made and then changed because someone has an issue. This slows down a lot of momentum. But the product is hot, so focus on the main business does not typically have issues.

Pros: Relaxing, fun atmosphere, with knowledgeable and professional co-workers. Amenities at work are good, and compensation is fair, if not good. The goals we worked toward were worthwhile.
Cons: The company doesn't do much to spread the benefits of working for them around. HQ got most of the attention when it came to amenities. Where I worked, on the operations side, there was not a lot of upward mobility. Most employees in my department were hired as contractors, and there seemed to be little consideration for them in the greater corporate plan.

Review Title: Great coworkers and work-life balance, but few opportunities for long-term career growth
Pros: Relaxed environment with great Work-life balance - Friendly and fun coworkers - fantastic culture - great environment to be in if this is your first corporate job or new to gaming or tech in general
Cons: a lot of emphasis on seniority rather than merit during promotions and performance reviews - Favoritism shown by executive management towards certain groups - Difficult to grow career-wise - No attempt to retain top talent--many high-performing employees poached by top companies - Below market pay

Pros: Free games, swag, and other discounted PS related merch and devices.
Cons: Benefits and pay are sub par compared to other Bay Area tech companies. This makes PS talent pool subpar as well. Had to move out because it was a top heavy org, no upward mobility despite high performance.

Pros: Met some great people, learned a lot about the industry. Sony does give decent benefits, also.
Cons: No training, difficult management--but in my department specifically, I can't speak for others. The company worked in silos for so long, bridging gaps is sometimes difficult. The open office floor plan is awful for certain groups, and should have been optional.

Pros: Got a lot of time to play and met really cool people. We were able to play the games earlier than the rest of the word and that was awesome.
Cons: Had played that much that my job was not being done hence got fired. The next time i will wait untill i finish my job so i can play

Review Title: Fun, Interesting but Yellow Badge BAD
Pros: Projects are really fun and interesting. Co-workers are smart and good fun to be around. My supervisor was hardworking but easy-going and very supportive of the team.
Cons: Difficult to navigate politics with a few key people clearly holding the power & protecting themselves/friends--at times to detriment of business. Yellow badges are a nightmare. You have all of the responsibility but none of the protections or dignity of regular employees.

Review Title: Pay is good, culture could be better
Pros: The pay and benefits are good. Free games, discounts on other Sony stuff. Good amount of PTO. Coworkers are nice and helpful.
Cons: Management does not communicate well. Sometimes unsure of expectations. Not sure of what is important. Supervisor is secretive and sneaky. Not trustworthy or helpful when problems come up.

Pros: It's a gaming company and there are quite a few perks that go with that like relaxed social atmosphere and dress code
Cons: Management is very confused and out of touch and manage the company through a series of disparate fiefdoms without aligned goals or a cohesive strategy.

Pros: Great company and good culture
Cons: However, there are some really bad managers who makes it deliberately difficult for everyone that are working under them and with them. Some notable mentions are perfeng and cicd team managers, for their awful and confrontational management style.

Pros: It's an easy job. It is considered experience in the video game field. Casual dress.
Cons: This is only as a QA tester. Intimidated into working overtime. It was alluded to that you would lose your job if you opt out (which I did after 6 straight months of doing it). Overtime was, and is common to be 12 hours a day 6 days a week and an 8 hour shift on Sundays. I was diagnosed with carpal tunnel issues in both of my wrists due to this overtime but was still asked to do the overtime as soon as the doctor released me.

Pros: Social dynamic is great. Office atmosphere is casual. Compensation is good. In San Diego location you can bring dogs on campus. The company has a operates like a startup without budget issues.
Cons: No direction from uppen management. Very difficult to be promoted within the company. No good direction for improvement. Entry to mid level employees are hardly noticed

Pros: The benefits are good. The San Diego campus is easy to get to and in a great location commute-wise. When you speak up, your direct management will listen. Management makes an effort to help push you forward with your own career goals in mind.
Cons: Needs more accountability on the individual scale. People hurt productivity by not understanding their own roles better in the development process.

Review Title: Great company and workforce - needs better focus on opportunity advancement and resourcing
Role: Senior software development engineer in test (sdet)
Pros: Fun things to work on Work/Life Balance Highly skilled individuals Equipment, office, and general community is very strong
Cons: Resourcing is always a problem in satellite offices Satellite offices have drastically reduced compensation for similar work Politics Bonus structure used as "motivation" to work extra hours

Pros: It's an awesome brand to be a part of. You can find some great people here and have the opportunity to be a part of some very cool projects.
Cons: Career paths and growth potential feel near non-existant, employees feel out of the loop and unfortunately often unappreciated. It does sometimes feel like they depend on the brand name to bring in top-talent, but it doesn't seem that top-talent stay very long. Some departments are in need of a complete overhaul from a talent perspective.

Pros: Benefits are decent and the pay is around or above market value for the area. Most employees are pretty friendly and laid back. Work is interesting and challenging. Management is pretty tech savvy.
Cons: Not too much interaction between different teams. Most people don't know what other teams are working on. Management structure is pretty flat so there is little room for career progression.

Pros: Fast-paced, works like a startup, working with newest technologies and building a lot of new applications and processes. Open to innovation. Very nice people. Small enough, yet solving big problems. Great product. Pays well
Cons: Some political vestiges of old regimes and people not understanding that we need to move forward and quickly. Some silo mentality that blocks quick implementation and execution

Pros: You don't have to worry about getting fired. They operate like a studio instead of a technology company so it's easy to get up to speed.
Cons: Good Ideas never see the light of day and bad Ideas never get killed. Japanese culture instills a process of conscious which is extremely detrimental in a technology company. No one is given decision making power.

Review Title: Overall a very good company to work for.
Pros: People are friendly, easy going and motivated. I see this when we have people volunteer for a flash mob dance at a recent event and also during a habitat for humanity outside the country. Everyone is also focused on the department goals and work in general.
Cons: For my department. No to little upward mobility and one has to check positions from other department although management has implemented some exposure (i.e. shadowing people) to other departments and other positions.

Review Title: Worst place to work for. Promote office bullies across the entire sales department.
Pros: Free coffee and milk. Free food and old games ocassionally.
Cons: Salaries are not competitive, and much lower than other companies in the area. Career advancement is driven by favorism, not ability, performance, or hardwork. Managers and directors abuse their power, bully, and mistreat employees. Their behaviors are unprofessional and immature like high school bulliers than working professionals. People do nothing due to fear for their career. Many support or even copy these behaviors creating toxic work environment across the entire sales department.

Pros: Always something new and exciting. Opportunity to work with awesome people, work in a true multinational corporation. Opportunity to learn lots of new technologies and work on diverse products. Always popular when find out you work at Playstation. Always learning. Amazing benefits.
Cons: With a full multinational company its never truly asleep to learning to adapt to an environment that follows the sun takes time. Sometimes takes a bit longer to reach consensus .

Review Title: Decent company with fun end products
Pros: Benefits are good, and some of the people are great.
Cons: Employee experience will differ greatly between work units. Company as a whole does not function as a single unit, but rather many different companies with no real common goal or direction. Most support groups have the sell their services to internal groups. Egos run big in this company. Have seen successful programs shut down because a different group felt they should be in control.

Pros: Good benefits, Nice campus, my team is great and we get to Work on really cool products that consumers love - Leadership team at PlayStation is getting better, I can see they are making strides to make PlayStation a competitive workplace in the Bay Area
Cons: - Career development is a bit unclear, but HR is working on improving - Work/life balance is a struggle - It's discouraging to see employees skate by and slack off get away with it, especially when some of the teams work so hard

Pros: If you can find a great team, the experience will be very rewarding. Lots of room to try new things and grow across a spectrum of possibilities.
Cons: A bit Aimless. Unless the teams are making a sequel to an existing title there's a lot of waste spent trying to figure out what the next title should be.

Pros: Benefits are competitive, bonuses vary but are generally decent, potential for variety of work, dedicated employee base, considered generally prestigious to be employee
Cons: Management structure can be nebulous, many silos within company, job security not what it once was as temporary employees more widely used to contain benefit costs, lots of fat in middle management

Pros: SNEI offers good benefits, good salary, casual and amicable atmosphere, opportunities for improvement and training.The company keeps growing and there is a lot of diversity, teams are very helpful.
Cons: Work is constant and very aggressive, need improvement on their processes and standards. Need to balance some work, some teams are overworked.

Pros: Liked the people I worked with. Everyone genuinely wants to do great things but efficient decision making is lacking. Great bonuses. Fun environment.
Cons: Lots of politics in a local and global level. Slow to create progress or make decisions, which almost always bars creativity and great work from being completed. You do the same thing all the time with every program. Pay is far below industry average. A. If culture of fear.

Pros: Nice colleagues to work with Offices in central london Free drinks and free fruit Free Gym
Cons: Incredibly disorganized company Blame culture Manager not qualified Heavy workload due to the useless manager not able to take responsability. I was working in a small team of 4 with the manager that was there just to supervising us - not even able to long into the system or to provide training to new starters. Awful experience. Plus the company does not support or value their employees!!! shame on you Sony Playstation

Pros: -They hire people you want to work with; they become your family (in a good way) -The company is trying to make it worth a place you want to stay
Cons: -Not every department is equal: some departments are the "fun" cool departments and others are the hard gruelling, no work-balance department -There are some lazy people who work here and stay because leadership lacks the ablilty to let go of lazy people

Review Title: PlayStation is just as fun as you would imagine.
Pros: The culture is very open and everything revolves around the consumer which is something I havent seen in many other companies. The way that management gives freedom to its groups allows for greater creative freedom to develop ideas (always taking into consideration the needs of its consumers)
Cons: Sony corporate policies can sometimes overshadow the PS irrelevant culture. Bureaucracy and antiquated processes create some major frustrations when it comes to executions.

Pros: Good people, Fun atmosphere, Flexible environment, Events, Discounts
Cons: Low pay No benefits Lack of opportunities to move up - despite their facade of "attempts" to promote. Layoffs abound Be prepared to do the job of a higher paying position, without the pay increase, benefits or title.

Pros: manages external expectations & adaptable to internal capacity. - Upwards trajectory in terms of culture, projects, outlook
Cons: Friends will ask you every week if you can get them a discounted PS55 - Not as quick as a start-up

Pros: Really relaxed environment with lots of really chill people. Definitely get to see a lot of diversity in the studios - and everyone here has a huge passion for the gaming industry
Cons: Little disorganized and frustrating trying to get things through higher corporate levels. Sometimes too many different departments and it can be confusing as to who's in charge of what.

Review Title: Great products and fun environment; Lacking Senior Leadership
Pros: Great products and a total blast to work with the fun people. Good competitive industry full of great smart people.
Cons: Lack of direction from Senior Management. Don't take great care of employees as it is a 'privilege' to work there. Not competitive salaries for same reason.

Review Title: A place best suited for entry to mid level developers and managers; experienced professionals need not apply
Pros: company name recognition; fairly flexible hours outside crunch times; values testing and quality assurance
Cons: Crunch times occur often; below average pay rate (common to have salary / bonuses haggled); management changes / reverses design and/or implemenation decisions mid-sprint / mid-project regularly

Pros: Motivating work if you have an interest in video games, and especially in PlayStation itself. People are friendly, and there is opportunity for growth.
Cons: Compensation seems lower than other companies in the computer entertainment industry. There are some organizational silos between groups. Each group looks after holding its own interest instead of working as a whole.

Pros: Great work environment, interesting work, cool people... Lots of training, good budget for gear. Management is competent. Results oriented.
Cons: None. Anything negative I might say would be petty. I guess you could say that we have more work than we could possibly do (and we do) but the management knows this, and doesn't make people work themselves to death to do the impossible. They set priorities. But there's just not enough time in the day!

Review Title: Pay is good, culture could be better
Pros: The pay and benefits are good. Free games, discounts on other Sony stuff. Good amount of PTO. Coworkers are nice and helpful.
Cons: Management does not communicate well. Sometimes unsure of expectations. Not sure of what is important. Supervisor is secretive and sneaky. Not trustworthy or helpful when problems come up.

Pros: It's a gaming company and there are quite a few perks that go with that like relaxed social atmosphere and dress code
Cons: Management is very confused and out of touch and manage the company through a series of disparate fiefdoms without aligned goals or a cohesive strategy.

Pros: Great company and good culture
Cons: However, there are some really bad managers who makes it deliberately difficult for everyone that are working under them and with them. Some notable mentions are perfeng and cicd team managers, for their awful and confrontational management style.

Pros: It's an easy job. It is considered experience in the video game field. Casual dress.
Cons: This is only as a QA tester. Intimidated into working overtime. It was alluded to that you would lose your job if you opt out (which I did after 6 straight months of doing it). Overtime was, and is common to be 12 hours a day 6 days a week and an 8 hour shift on Sundays. I was diagnosed with carpal tunnel issues in both of my wrists due to this overtime but was still asked to do the overtime as soon as the doctor released me.

Pros: Social dynamic is great. Office atmosphere is casual. Compensation is good. In San Diego location you can bring dogs on campus. The company has a operates like a startup without budget issues.
Cons: No direction from uppen management. Very difficult to be promoted within the company. No good direction for improvement. Entry to mid level employees are hardly noticed

Pros: The benefits are good. The San Diego campus is easy to get to and in a great location commute-wise. When you speak up, your direct management will listen. Management makes an effort to help push you forward with your own career goals in mind.
Cons: Needs more accountability on the individual scale. People hurt productivity by not understanding their own roles better in the development process.

Review Title: Great company and workforce - needs better focus on opportunity advancement and resourcing
Role: Senior software development engineer in test (sdet)
Pros: Fun things to work on Work/Life Balance Highly skilled individuals Equipment, office, and general community is very strong
Cons: Resourcing is always a problem in satellite offices Satellite offices have drastically reduced compensation for similar work Politics Bonus structure used as "motivation" to work extra hours

Pros: It's an awesome brand to be a part of. You can find some great people here and have the opportunity to be a part of some very cool projects.
Cons: Career paths and growth potential feel near non-existant, employees feel out of the loop and unfortunately often unappreciated. It does sometimes feel like they depend on the brand name to bring in top-talent, but it doesn't seem that top-talent stay very long. Some departments are in need of a complete overhaul from a talent perspective.

Pros: Benefits are decent and the pay is around or above market value for the area. Most employees are pretty friendly and laid back. Work is interesting and challenging. Management is pretty tech savvy.
Cons: Not too much interaction between different teams. Most people don't know what other teams are working on. Management structure is pretty flat so there is little room for career progression.

Pros: Fast-paced, works like a startup, working with newest technologies and building a lot of new applications and processes. Open to innovation. Very nice people. Small enough, yet solving big problems. Great product. Pays well
Cons: Some political vestiges of old regimes and people not understanding that we need to move forward and quickly. Some silo mentality that blocks quick implementation and execution

Pros: You don't have to worry about getting fired. They operate like a studio instead of a technology company so it's easy to get up to speed.
Cons: Good Ideas never see the light of day and bad Ideas never get killed. Japanese culture instills a process of conscious which is extremely detrimental in a technology company. No one is given decision making power.

Review Title: Overall a very good company to work for.
Pros: People are friendly, easy going and motivated. I see this when we have people volunteer for a flash mob dance at a recent event and also during a habitat for humanity outside the country. Everyone is also focused on the department goals and work in general.
Cons: For my department. No to little upward mobility and one has to check positions from other department although management has implemented some exposure (i.e. shadowing people) to other departments and other positions.

Review Title: Worst place to work for. Promote office bullies across the entire sales department.
Pros: Free coffee and milk. Free food and old games ocassionally.
Cons: Salaries are not competitive, and much lower than other companies in the area. Career advancement is driven by favorism, not ability, performance, or hardwork. Managers and directors abuse their power, bully, and mistreat employees. Their behaviors are unprofessional and immature like high school bulliers than working professionals. People do nothing due to fear for their career. Many support or even copy these behaviors creating toxic work environment across the entire sales department.

Pros: Always something new and exciting. Opportunity to work with awesome people, work in a true multinational corporation. Opportunity to learn lots of new technologies and work on diverse products. Always popular when find out you work at Playstation. Always learning. Amazing benefits.
Cons: With a full multinational company its never truly asleep to learning to adapt to an environment that follows the sun takes time. Sometimes takes a bit longer to reach consensus .

Review Title: Decent company with fun end products
Pros: Benefits are good, and some of the people are great.
Cons: Employee experience will differ greatly between work units. Company as a whole does not function as a single unit, but rather many different companies with no real common goal or direction. Most support groups have the sell their services to internal groups. Egos run big in this company. Have seen successful programs shut down because a different group felt they should be in control.

Pros: Good benefits, Nice campus, my team is great and we get to Work on really cool products that consumers love - Leadership team at PlayStation is getting better, I can see they are making strides to make PlayStation a competitive workplace in the Bay Area
Cons: Career development is a bit unclear, but HR is working on improving - Work/life balance is a struggle - It's discouraging to see employees skate by and slack off get away with it, especially when some of the teams work so hard

Pros: If you can find a great team, the experience will be very rewarding. Lots of room to try new things and grow across a spectrum of possibilities.
Cons: A bit Aimless. Unless the teams are making a sequel to an existing title there's a lot of waste spent trying to figure out what the next title should be.

Pros: Benefits are competitive, bonuses vary but are generally decent, potential for variety of work, dedicated employee base, considered generally prestigious to be employee
Cons: Management structure can be nebulous, many silos within company, job security not what it once was as temporary employees more widely used to contain benefit costs, lots of fat in middle management

Pros: SNEI offers good benefits, good salary, casual and amicable atmosphere, opportunities for improvement and training.The company keeps growing and there is a lot of diversity, teams are very helpful.
Cons: Work is constant and very aggressive, need improvement on their processes and standards. Need to balance some work, some teams are overworked.

Pros: Liked the people I worked with. Everyone genuinely wants to do great things but efficient decision making is lacking. Great bonuses. Fun environment.
Cons: Lots of politics in a local and global level. Slow to create progress or make decisions, which almost always bars creativity and great work from being completed. You do the same thing all the time with every program. Pay is far below industry average. A. If culture of fear.

Pros: It is a good name to have on your resume. You will add substantially to your network. Good facilities.
Cons: Poisonous environments where departments are fighting turf wars against each other. Little to no leadership Initiative is not rewarded nor encouraged. Sony is very much a sinking ship living on past glories.

Pros: Great perks, beautiful headquarters, people are open, genuine, and helpful. Best part is working on so many great titles and the pride that comes with it.
Cons: It's such a big company that it's very difficult to advance. Growth comes to a halt and skills are only relevant to role that you get pigeonholed into.

Pros: The people and culture are great. Discounts on most Sony products. Great place to start your career.
Cons: I stay because not all the senior management is bad, but SNEI has some of the worst senior managers ever. Big egos, no direction, no planning, public ridicule, micro micro micro management.

Review Title: Friendly Environment But Lack of Opportunities to Progress
Pros: Friendly environment to work in. Good pension and healthcare. Social aspect can be great and have made many friends over the years working there.
Cons: Not many opportunities to progress. Very little training given. No room to move around in the company as people tend to stay in the positions for a long time.

Pros: Great exposure to the company's senior leadership and the larger technology, media and entertainment industry. Great work life balance and fun events keep you engaged throughout and ensure that you mingle and learn as much from cross functional teams as your own.
Cons: I cannot think of any cons that are of critical importance for anyone who is considering working at Sony. All I can say is that you as an intern must also be as proactive in learning as much during your term.

Pros: Whimsical and creative production environment.
Cons: Still has an antiquated "top down" management approach. Confining structure and to stodgy for the bay area. Questionable ethical behavior among some senior management folk. No stock options or RSUs.

Pros: Friendly place, good tech, interesting ideas depending on team, not too hung up on process, but there is some, it is a large corporation.
Cons: Things can move slowly, bean counter now running London office. pay can be lower as they are SONY :)

Pros: Lots of parties Work from home option (1-2 times/ week) not lot of work pressure except holiday season
Cons: No clear road map for technology Teams are spread over different places Outstanding performance has no relevance to promotion Promotions are backfill based on if someone in management leaves the company Salaries are bay area average No carpool benefit or company bus for commute

Review Title: A lot of amazing people to work with but pay very poorly
Pros: A lot of amazing and smart people A lot of interesting technology to work on
Cons: Really bad pay compared to other companies You rarely will be doing R&D work. Salary bonus is a joke. Most of the time people get 4% of salary bonus

Review Title: The best place I’ve ever worked.
Pros: I am so fortunate to work at a place where the employees are so highly valued. I don’t even know where to start- the work is fun, engaging and challenging. Leadership treats us with respect, and the benefits are unbelievable. The company culture makes me feel right at home.
