Pros: Many people are in their dream jobs, making video games for a living. Really smart, hard working people in a mostly relaxed, fun atmosphere. Generous training policy.
Cons: Game teams definitely have to crunch near title launch. Some game projects get cancelled; that's just the nature of the industry. Most managers have promoted through technical or design backgrounds. Very few have strong management skills.

Pros: Some very good people to work with, nice location, decent perks.
Cons: If your VP is connected well, your group will do well. Pick the wrong horse and your department will get absorbed into a different one. That's not unique to this place. Future outlook is murky. Vita needs to do better. Everything is riding on ps4. If it doesn't do well, it will be the end.

Pros: Sony is a large company with lots of hardware and software opportunities, people coming into Sony are excited to be part of what could be an amazing place for innovation within design and engineering.
Cons: Massive amount of blocking from self-promoting management on ideas and innovation. Most people leave within a year, them that stay are locked by political handcuffs.

Review Title: Exciting place as a software engineer.
Pros: If you have a good engineering skill, there are a lot of opportunities to be engaged in state-of-the-art gaming technology. There are also a lot of talented people and you can build good connections.
Cons: It is difficult to change the efficiency of the development process. It seems a bit inefficient to me. Because of lack of training aid, you need to improve your skill by yourself. Good external connections will help you a lot.

Pros: Some of the best people work here. Teams seem to want to help each other but can be territorial at times.
Cons: Murky management decisions. Sometimes it is hard to understand Japanese corporate culture. As a company ran from a far (Corporate is a separate entity) it can be frustrating when guiding decisions are mandated without consideration of each department unless they have a local representative fighting for them.

Review Title: Great place to start QA career, but the job is not guaranteed.
Pros: Chance to work on many different titles, paid holidays, fair amount of secondment opportunities, summer/winter parties, free snacks + fruit.
Cons: You start off as a contractor, meaning you could lose your job at any moment, most the people I started with were fired. You also don't get as many benefits as permanent staff, no sick pay.

Review Title: Great place if you're into videogames. Management was questionable as they were "worker bees" versus "leaders."
Pros: Average benefits and good discount off of Sony consumer electronics. Good place for kids straight out of college to work.
Cons: Not only is every division of Sony Corp in separate silos, but each dept at SCEA is in different silos. Company lacks future vision of the Kutaragi years and plateau'd after PS3 launched.

Pros: Atmosphere, management (locally, at least). Not a corporate environment. Creative, driven people.
Cons: Location in Playa Vista a bit remote. In the rare instances of having to deal with "corporate" (HR, Finance), I am driven to madness.

Review Title: Politics are ruining the previous energetic atmosphere
Pros: The people are great for the most part, everyone buckles down and gets things shipped when crunch time, and nobody gets on our case when there's a light workload.
Cons: I hadn't heard of a real firing for years, but now it's rampant. Demotions are all the craze these days, the atmosphere from we're getting from the top is that they don't care about us. They fired our scrum masters, I have yet to meet one person who thinks this was a good decision - everyone agrees that it sucks. The bureaucratic nonsense is frustrating - copy everything from one website and place it to another site to show other people who don't like looking at the first site. This new crew is causing gossip where there was very little before, they are scaring everyone away and there is no end in sight, and no positive gain either.

Review Title: Not All Groups are Same-Toxic Management in My Group
Pros: Some of the tools and processes were fun to work with. I tried creating my processes and had fun doing that
Cons: I heard some other groups are fun and good to work with but I worked for the Business Analytics group within Operations and it was very stressful! Assigned work did not match people's skill sets. QAs were asked to do BAs work and vice versa. Favoritism and micromanagement runs high in the group. Several people have left or were let go. If you apply for Sony, other groups may be fine but not this group. Cons outweigh the pros in this group.

Pros: Encouraged to try new things - my team lead promotes creativity and supports efforts toward improvements. Personal development is encouraged. Great compensation and love all the cool perks (such as free donut Fridays, PlayStation vouchers, video consoles in the lobby, access to great gym).
Cons: A small minority of folks are not open to change - but this is not unusual to a company so is not really a unique con.

Review Title: No leadership, toxic culture, avoid RB location at all cost.
Pros: decent office space good facility including a cafe, gym and indoor garage
Cons: pay below market level performance/promotions measured by distance from leaders few capable line managers rampant office bullying no care of employees' life work balance

Pros: Fun working environment, great work/life balance. Great on site cafe and work out facility
Cons: Management, management, management. Either good manager but, not strong enough to outweigh bad popular strategies for the company or bad manager with 'power' to make non strategic or profitable decisions for the company. There are definitely some good/strong managers in the bunch.

Pros: Amazing brand with products that customers love. You get the resources you need to get the job done. Plenty of smart, talented people across the company.
Cons: It's part of a much larger global corporation with many different divisions, so you'll have to deal with the red tape and silos that are typical of large companies.

Review Title: A hot mess of employment law violations
Pros: Big name titles Looks great on CV Good freebies
Cons: New HR teams more interested in protecting management and "segregating" Sony from Yoh Bullying allowed to occur frequently with targets of abuse being punished or forced out Sexual harassment swept under the carpet Rampant favoritism

Review Title: At Sony Format QA, the atomosphere of the work place is very friendly and relaxing.
Pros: Most permanent QA testers stick around for a long time and no one quits volunteerly.
Cons: There are some child-ish customs and regulations set by the management at FQA department (set by the supervisor).

Pros: New campus and cafeteria are nice. Good product that gamers are enthusiastic about.
Cons: Outdated corporate culture, slow to adapt to new technology. Hasn't incorporated the mobile culture that now dominates silicon valley. Nepotism across the organization, candidates are hired and receive promotions based on previous business relationships. The existing workforce though qualified, stagnates. Open reqs get filled through the back door and then posted to 'Career Opprtunities'.

Pros: great company with a great work culture
Cons: there needs to be better onboarding documentation

Review Title: Absurdly backwards place to work. Gives the game industry a bad name.
Pros: - Good for your CV Many companies will be impressed by your Sony Playstation experience in future interviews. - Suitable as a "job-between-jobs" Meaning if you're thinking of leaving your current job, use this position while you look for your next one as it's only beneficial as a short-term solution.
Cons: - Supports 'crunch culture' I found myself being immensely overworked during a deadline period of a project. Overtime pay is decided by the managers. It is commonly known amongst employees that rejecting an offer of overtime will inevitably become one of the reasons to terminate your role. Project management is disgustingly unprepared and unplanned which leads to many times to crunch. This should not be happening anymore in this industry. - Extremely toxic office culture Office is one big clique and is full of favouritism. If you don't believe in becoming friends with a certain group of people then your time there will be short. It seems that only people inside this clique are the ones to become promoted or be given work on the bigger, more exciting projects. - "Yoh!" Yoh is a staffing/outsourcing company. When you work as a contract tester for Playstation, you're actually working for Yoh and will get few, if not none of the Playstation benefits. Yoh as a company also bankrolls the U.S military and U.S firearms and this is something that will get your contract terminated if you're caught talking about while in the office. - Zero job security You've probably already picked this up from the points above, but as a functional tester you have zero job security. You will have a rolling contract which can be terminated at any time. You will be constantly reinforced by test leads and managers that you're doing a good job and that there's nothing to worry about, only to be handed your termination letter a week later. - Disgusting Salary During my time there I was earning less than £15,000 p/y which went up by a small amount every year, and I can imagine it's probably just over that now. It's better than nothing, obviously, but be aware that they're not paying you what you're worth, and they take advantage of that while they earn more than triple. Here's a piece of advice: You can get a permanent testing role in most (better) game companies for at the very least £18,000 p/y or even more if you move down South.

Review Title: Close to Decade of service. Decent and sometimes disorganized functionality
Pros: Make you own schedule and route. Community outreach was encouraged
Cons: No upward mobility. Sometimes a divide between how Reps were treated and how corporate workers were treated. Projects were unpredictable at times forcing reps to choose between family life and satisfying the interjected project.

Review Title: Fun company but lots of politics
Pros: Great brand and product Amazing office location Opportunities to work on interesting projects
Cons: Pay is less than the industry average You don't get competitive pay increases each year - need to move to keep in line with the industry A lot of internal politics Like with most companies of this size, the next restructure is never far away

Pros: Some are very talented people. The Japanese I work with are very open. Not a company that is afraid of making things.
Cons: A lot of reorgs in the last 2 years. Hard to get things done. Lots of politics. Sometimes too many people in meetings not getting enough done.

Pros: SCEA has excellent benefits, and working there provides the opportunity to contribute to world class technology on a leading gaming console.
Cons: Getting onto the right team is critical as some teams run like a well oiled machine while others are unfathomably dysfunctional.

Review Title: Used to be the greatest place to work
Pros: Creative, highly motivated environment. A dream job for an engineer. Japanese company loyal to employees. Good at life work balance.
Cons: Sinking industry. Sinking company. Short-sighted and inept management. Terrible at keeping talent. Disfunctinal teams all across departments. In spite of much effort, lots of silos across the organization.

Pros: Fun place to work. Cool products and great brand. Video game industry is very dynamic and fast paced. Great perks and discounts on products.
Cons: Hard to move and advance within the organization. Highly political and senior management does not do a very good job of promoting or mentoring.

Pros: It's a stable and big company - some perks that come because of that
Cons: Horrible management, rampant use of H1bs at lower levels, management doesn't really care about measurable outcomes - all that matters is how you look to upper management. If you are actually talented or good at what you do, don't come here

Pros: Great place with friendly fun co-workers. - Room to grow professionally. - Family environment. - Great work life balance, if you want it.
Cons: - Low salary for industry and especially low for Silicon Valley. - Top talent gets poached by top 3 companies (FB, Google, Apple). - No attempt to retain top talent. - Nepotism

Review Title: Decent place to start, but not enough opportunities for long term career.
Pros: People are friendly, relaxed office atmosphere, free snacks/fruits and a solid place to get a foundation level of QA experience.
Cons: Not enough opportunities for a long term career, there is lots of competition for senior positions, training is rushed but you get the hang of things quickly.

Review Title: Great place to work but not a great deal of opportunity to progress
Pros: Great people, culture and generally a fun place to work
Cons: Not a lot of opportunity to progress and can end up pigeon holed in the industry. Generally systems and technology aren't at the level you would expect. Salaries and packages aren't at the level you would expect

Pros: On-site cafeteria, on-site fitness center, library of low-end PlayStation games, free beverages. The majority of the engineers and middle-level management are great to work with.
Cons: The untouchable new "leadership" kills all desire to be productive as everyone is scared to open their mouth or make a wrong move. Any previous creativity has been replaced by fear.

Review Title: Great place to work for those who embrace challenge
Pros: Exciting, dynamic, always changing and lots of opportunity for those who are self motivated
Cons: Always changing which may be a challenge for those who do not like to keep reinventing themselves

Review Title: So much potential, yet such a bad work environment
Pros: So many fun challenges of a growing business, there are some real interesting problems to solve.
Cons: SNEI does not provide an environment where creativity, out of the box thinking and intelligence is rewarded. In fact, it's the opposite. People with mediocre technical and management skills but great political skills are rewarded, and change is highly discouraged. No one manages downward, everyone is managing upwards, and the mediocre managers are terrified that people will discover their lack of technical understanding and lack of management skills, this fuels a fear-driven culture. Good people get thrown under the bus all the time and they just leave. If you decide to do something that's good for the business, watch your back. Sadly, SNEI's approach to address the lack of collaboration is by introducing heaps and heaps of process/bureaucracy. Meetings are sad, no one listens to one another, people are just on their computers, not paying attention. I've seen executive VPs watch Youtube videos on their mobile phones during meetings. Upper management is so far removed from the daily layers of execution it's no surprise. It's as if there's no one at the helm of the ship. With all that said, there are pockets of solid teams under very competent managers that really work to create a collaborative environment, but they still seem to be the minority and in all cases these are managers that were hired from other companies.

Review Title: Far away from being comparable with big companies
Pros: Gaming company culture and people
Cons: While other companies are being extremely flexible with their employees, letting them work remotely from anywhere, SIE is making a big deal about it and not letting people work from a different location (outside California). There is no flexibility whatsoever in letting people move to a different campus, for example.

Pros: So much potential to revive one of the greats in the industry.
Cons: Slow to adapt and the risk aversion is preventing the organization from truly being nimble.

Pros: The projects I was able to work on was very rewarding (personally).
Cons: ...It was sad to know that management did not know my daily work, and were constantly asking what I was working on every day. I thought that as a manager, this person should definitely know what I'm working on, I mean, I got hired for the specified job that was listed right?

Pros: Wonderful culture, great people, fun place to work, good benefits, beautiful main campus, creative, and if you love video games, this is the place for you
Cons: Depending on the role you are in, there is limited mobility unless you move to a different department or function. Cost of living in the Bay Area is nuts...

Pros: Good Benefits Latest Technology Company on profits
Cons: You are asked to work outside of office hours. You are expected to be on mobile. You have to deal with persons who are politically motivated. no cooperation between teams. Back talking against you.

Pros: Great benefits like a decent pension scheme, profit share and top health insurance. They offer plenty of clear career paths and courses and resources to improve.

Cons: Still lots of hangovers from the Psygnosis days. Some reticence to change. Sony are generally reluctant to try something radical and new.

Pros: Great life-work balance. Fast growing company, creating many opportunities to impact the organization
Cons: Though the brand name suggests cutting edge technology, the company is behind in so many aspects. I would love to see them not only catch up but leading the pack upholding the brand.

Pros: - People love the products, the PS4 in particular - Colleagues are great and fun - Good parties - Cool brand to work for
Cons: - Politics between EMEA and US especially - People in leadership have been there a long time and can be conservative - Sony getting involved more which means the brand is a bit less cool

Review Title: Slow and steady but cutting edge
Pros: Good work/life balance (hours are reasonable) Amazing network/tech/security foundation and infrastructure Very smart Very stable product
Cons: Seems easy to get stuck being the sole owner of projects until someone leaves Needed a culture club to try and breath some life into the office environment C level execs were mostly absent. CEO made an appearance once every couple months. CTO seems to be on permanent vacation (seriously).

Review Title: Seemed like a great opportunity, but was one of the worst jobs of my life
Pros: I got a ton of free games in the three months I was employed as a PlayStation Representative. I liked being able to set my own schedule to a certain extent.
Cons: Where do I begin. The pay is incredibly low for the amount of work you have to do. Getting shipped boxes every week and opening and organizing them all the time is time consuming in itself. My favorite account to work with was GameStop. I think the KPI metrics need to be revisited. Associate Engagement is a complete waste of time when Target, Best Buy, and Wal-Mart employees don't really care. There are a rare few that do though in those accounts. I received a warning for scheduling a day off on a day I was originally planning to work at the last minute. However, when you need to constantly schedule demo events and product trainings and a store calls you to confirm, sometimes you need to make last minute changes to avoid overtime, which is it what I did. I felt micro managed, which is something I despise. Just let me schedule my stores and events and you can view that in ROAM. The ROAM software is complete garbage. It's slow and I got a warning I wasn't writing detailed comments for my visits. Well, in the surveys, you ask what I'm doing, so I don't feel a need to write it down twice. Time keeping is a joke in itself. They need to really use Workday or Shift Planning or some other time tracking app because entering time in ADP and ROAM and then calculating your drive time is a mess in itself. HR told me I could work as much OT as I wanted, but I got a warning the first time I did, so I felt lied to. All in all, I didn't have a work/life balance and that is moist important to me.

Review Title: Can be great if you are in the right spot.
Pros: All the fun and challenge that comes with working on Sony entertainment products.
Cons: Ego-intoxication. Those few immature (regardless of age) managers in Japan, US and UK who skillfully undermine the company in service of their personal ambition.

Review Title: Great place to work and have fun
Pros: Decent salary with annual bonus. Free games and great discount on Sony's game and electronic products. Good people around you including management.
Cons: Not the highest paid salary with small raise each year. Some free food but not every day like Google. Few employee activities.

Pros: Great collaborative environment. Most talented pool of dedicated and passionate employees. If you like being a part of creative and fun work enviroment-apply at playstation :)
Cons: I felt that there were limited opportunities for women. Predominantly male-centric company. Lack of internal promotability which results in attrition of key talent.

Pros: Stability, job security. It's very unlikely that people are fired or "let go" in Japan. They simply "move" people to the most mundane positions/teams in the hope that they will just quit. (Just google "japan forcing-out rooms"). I even know of a woman who is a complete alcoholic and pretty much just sleeps at her desk all day, but no one can fire her. Japanese rules! So if that appeals to you then it could be classed as a "pro". Lots of nice people work here. Genuinely nice and polite people - even upper management. Not so much overtime. This was a concern for me because we've all heard of those crazy hours that the Japanese work, but actually in my team we do a 10 - 6:30 day. Occasionally people stay a bit later but its rare. Other teams (engineers & developers) seem to do longer hours but I'm not sure. Canteen/food court - meals are generally good with lots of choice and basically quite cheap (yes, not free). Typically a lunch meal comes to 600 - 800 yen. You can sleep anywhere and at anytime. Seriously, people sleep at their desks, in meetings (oh yes!), in the communal areas...pretty much anywhere. I've never done this, but it seems acceptable.
Cons: The work environment and atmosphere are torture. Seriously, it is not a surprise that people commit suicide as much as they do (oh yes they really do). This isn't a problem specific to Sony HQ of course, many Japanese companies suffer from this. But honestly, the office space is cramped, dark, messy, overcrowded, outdated and very bleak. Hard to stay positive some days! The "salaryman" salaries are low in Japan. Seriously, nothing compared to EU or US. Plus there are no benefits - seriously, nothing. No discounts on PS (or Sony products), no freebies, no launch parties, no Xmas parties (well, we get a 2 hour bingo session with a few drinks and snacks), no training to non-Japanese, no off-site team-building...we even pay individually when our manager calls for a team meal & drinks in the evening. You get your salary, you get your bonus and that's it. Very little chance for career development. Japanese people work for years and years until they are "the right age" just to finally get promoted to team leader of manager. There is very little internal movement opportunities for non-Japanese. 8 months ago I contacted HR to express my interest in broadening my career by moving to a new team or at least hearing of any internal opportunities, after a brief response confirming that they understood my request I never heard from them again. Toilets- there are 26 floors and each floor has about 300+ people (mostly men), yet there are just 9 cubicles on each floor. People actually queue up and wait outside the cubicles. There's a clock-in / clock-out system. You know how you see in old movies of factory workers punching their cards in and out? Well, now its digital but basically the same. And if you are not making core hours for the month then you are forced to use your annual holiday. Seriously, I missed core hours by 1 minute once - yes, just 1 minute - and I was told by HR that I must use half a day holiday.

Review Title: Decent company, but hostile environment in my department.
Pros: It is rewarding to have a career at this company if you are passionate about the industry and about being part of the whole picture.
Cons: There is poor work/life balance for the majority of the departments and the politics you find at companies of this size.

Review Title: Great as a career starter only

Cons: - Poor internal communication - Unenthused staff - Very little reward or attention given for hard work - Poor/ odd managerial choices and a disconnect between higher ups and staff - Frequent cut backs on staff / redundancies

Pros: great work life balance, team atmosphere that keeps the energy up, lots of opportunities to grow and learn
Cons: there is a great work/life balance but sometimes there are days when you take your work home with you on weeknights or weekends

Pros: High end of technology. You are in the business of giving people fun experiences. Culture. People. It sounds clich, but it's true. A desire to deliver on the tag lines. People with passion.
Cons: There aren't a lot. Compensation and benefits not best. At least in my position, organizational weight sometimes.

Review Title: Great people, fun place to work but they dont appreciate or retain good people.

Cons: The way they treat good employees. They are not competitive with salaries and benefits. They dont make an effort to keep good employees. Best options is to leave and come back to get the raise you want.

Review Title: Low salary, almost impossible to grow professionally.
Pros: Nice people, flexible schedule. Paid Christmas shutdown. Decent benefits.

Review Title: Needs to get real /experienced games leaders in place who know game dev and people management.
Pros: You get to work for Sony. You get to work on new tech and some well good peoples. Den Plan is quite good also.
Cons: Management unsupportive and no focus on process. Quick to blame others for short comings, weekend working is also a norm.

Review Title: Good company with lots of upside potential.

Cons: Work life balance can be a challenge. The company is currently experiencing a lot of internal change.

Review Title: Very fun internship that exposed me to a wide variety of PlayStation titles and technologies.
Pros: If you like working with Playstation titles and/or on Playstation tech, this is the place to be.
Cons: It is a very large company, and it can be easy to feel like you've been lost in the crowd.

Cons: Platform is big and old, not many opportunities to work on the latest technology. Unlike tech companies in San Francisco, nothing is free here, cafeteria and gym are over priced.

Pros: Good Benefits, competitive pay, good culture. It's a game company so fun projects and good times happen often.

Pros: Always a fun product to work on. The company invests in its employees, so long as you are willing to ask

Review Title: Great company where a bad management can destroy everything

Cons: Like any big business, bureaucracy and communication can become tangled up and make simple tasks more complicated than they need to be. It's something you can work around, but it takes time and effort.

Pros: Is a leading company and a will like to contribute with the expansion and grow with it
Cons: There is no downside to work at sony playstation network as i say is a growing company is the leading network at this moments and i will like to help by giving my knowledge to make ot better in anyways

Review Title: Great company with cool people and exciting projects

Review Title: I've been at Sony for 2.5 years

Pros: The company is very siloed so one group's experience may be quite a bit different than another, so take this with a grain of salt. Good benefits, good work/life balance, overall fun place to work, and good people.

Review Title: Can be good but trending down

Cons: Increasing pressure to do more with less... IOW- laying off people and having remaining folks take on the work.

Cons: Struggles with ageing office infrastructure.

Pay is far below the average in the area.

Review Title: Great company if you love video games.
